}} '''Keith Ross Miller''', {{post-nominals|country=AUS|AM|MBE}} (28 November 1919 – 11 October 2004) was an Australian test [[cricket]]er and a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] pilot during [[World War II]]. Miller is widely regarded as Australia's greatest ever [[all-rounder]].<ref name="BBCObit">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/australia/3733322.stm|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Oliver|last=Brett| title=Australia's greatest all-rounder|date=11 October 2004|accessdate=2 February 2009}}</ref> Because of his ability, irreverent manner and good looks he was a crowd favourite.<ref name="SMH">{{cite web|title=Death of a hero|first=Greg|last=Baum|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/10/11/1097406502446.html|work=[[The Age]]|date=11 October 2004|accessdate=2 February 2009}}</ref> English journalist [[Ian Wooldridge]] called Miller "the golden boy" of cricket, leading to his being nicknamed "[[Gold nugget|Nugget]]".<ref name="McNicoll">{{cite web| url=http://www.awm.gov.au/fiftyaustralians/32.asp |title=Keith Ross Miller, MBE (1919–2004) |publisher=[[Australian War Memorial]] |accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref> He "was more than a cricketer ... he embodied the idea that there was more to life than cricket".<ref name="Cricinfo">{{Cite web|url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/australia/content/player/6612.html |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |title=Players and Officials – Keith Miller |accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref>
A member of the record-breaking ''[[Australian cricket team in England in 1948|Invincibles]]'', at the time of his retirement from [[Test cricket]] in 1956, Miller had the best statistics of any all-rounder in cricket history.<ref name="BBCObit2">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/other_international/australia/3733322.stm|publisher=[[BBC]]|first=Oliver|last=Brett| title=Australia's greatest all-rounder|date=11 October 2004|accessdate=2 February 2009|quote=By the time Miller had retired after 55 tests, he had the finest all-round record in cricket history, with statistics that were only beaten in later eras. The second man, Wilfred Rhodes, was 663 runs and 43 wickets behind him}}</ref> He often batted high in the [[Batting order (cricket)|order]], sometimes as high as number three. He was a powerful striker of the ball, and one straight [[six (cricket)|six]] that he hit at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] was still rising when it hit the upper deck of the grandstand. Miller was famous for varying his [[bowling (cricket)|bowling]] to bemuse batsmen: he made sparing use of slower deliveries and would often adjust his run-up, surprisingly bowling his fastest deliveries from a short run. He was also a fine [[fielding (cricket)|fielder]] and an especially acrobatic catcher in the [[slips (cricket)|slips]].<ref name="Pollard"/>
Away from cricket, Miller was also a successful [[Australian rules football]]er. He played for [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] and was selected to represent the [[interstate matches in Australian rules football|Victorian state team]]. He played 50 games for St Kilda, for whom he kicked eight [[Laws of Australian football#Scoring|goal]]s in one game against North Melbourne, during 1941.<ref name="argus1941">[http://trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/8200431 ''The Argus'' 25.08.1941 p8]</ref>
Miller's personality — love of the contest, rather than victory, and his larger-than-life rebelliousness and carousing — helped both shape and limit his cricketing career, as he espoused the opposite of the more puritanical values of [[Donald Bradman]], his captain and later national selector. [[Neville Cardus]] referred to Miller as "the Australian in excelsis"; ''[[Daily Mail]]'' sportswriter [[Ian Wooldridge]]'s response was "By God he was right".<ref name="Cricinfo"/> This status was reflected when Miller was made one of the ten inaugural members of the [[Australian Cricket Hall of Fame]].
==Early years== {{main|Early life of Keith Miller}} [[File:Woodfull stance.jpg|thumb|upright|left|The Australian cricket captain [[Bill Woodfull]] was Miller's high school mathematics teacher.]] Born in the western [[Melbourne]] suburb of [[Sunshine, Victoria|Sunshine]], Miller was the youngest of Leslie and Edith Miller's four children.<ref name="p10"/><ref name="p11">Perry, p. 11.</ref><ref name=w42>Whitington, p. 42.</ref> He was named after the Australian pioneer aviator brothers [[Keith Macpherson Smith|Keith]] and [[Ross Macpherson Smith|Ross Smith]],<ref name=w42/><ref name=m61>Mallett, p. 61.</ref> who were half-way through their historic [[England to Australia flight|flight from England to Australia]] at the time Miller was born.<ref name="Pollard">{{cite book |last=Pollard |first=Jack |title=Australian Cricket:The Game and the Players |year=1988 |publisher=Angus & Robertson |location=Sydney |isbn=0-207-15269-1 |pages = 755–759 }}</ref><ref name="p10">Perry, p. 10.</ref> The three Miller boys played [[Australian rules football]] in winter and cricket in summer. Their father had been a successful local cricketer and taught the boys to play with an orthodox and classical technique,<ref name="p11"/> relying on a solid defence and concentration in the mould of [[Bill Ponsford]].<ref name="p12">Perry, p. 12.</ref> At the age of seven, Miller's family moved to [[Elsternwick, Victoria|Elsternwick]], in Melbourne's south east.<ref name="p12"/><ref name=w43>Whitington, p. 43.</ref> As a child, Miller was small for his age, which forced him to develop his technique rather than rely on power, something that held him in good stead for the future.<ref name="p13">Perry, p. 13.</ref><ref name=w45>Whitington, p. 45.</ref>
At the age of 12, he was selected for an under-15 Victorian schoolboys cricket team.<ref name="Coleman"/> At the time, he stood only {{convert|150|cm|ft|1}} tall and wielded a sawn-off bat.<ref name="p15"/> He lacked power, but impressed with his footwork and style.<ref name="p15">Perry, p. 15.</ref><ref name="p16">Perry, p. 16.</ref> However, Miller reasoned that, as he appeared destined to be short, a career as a jockey was more likely than one as a cricketer or footballer.<ref name="p17">Perry, p. 17.</ref><ref name=m64>Mallett, p. 64.</ref><ref name=w47>Whitington, p. 47.</ref>
Miller attended the selective [[Melbourne High School]],<ref name="p17"/> where [[Australia national cricket team|Australian]] [[Test cricket|test]] captain [[Bill Woodfull]] was his mathematics teacher.<ref name="Coleman">Coleman, pp. 473–478.</ref> Miller was a mediocre student,<ref name="p18">Perry, p. 18.</ref> which disappointed Woodfull;<ref name="p18"/> however, Woodfull quickly noticed Miller's cricket skills.<ref name="p19">Perry, p. 19.</ref> Aged 14, Miller was selected for the school's [[first XI]], scoring 44. His control and solidity prompted the spectators to call him ''The Unbowlable''—Woodfull's own nickname.<ref>A reference to [[Bowled]]</ref><ref name="p20">Perry, p. 20.</ref> In 1934, Miller failed all of his subjects, scoring zero in his final exam for Woodfull's geometry class, and was forced to repeat the year.<ref name="p21">Perry, p. 21.</ref><ref name="p22">Perry, p. 22.</ref>
[[Keith Truscott]], Miller's school cricket captain took him to a trial with local club side [[St Kilda Cricket Club|St Kilda]] at the start of the 1934–35 season, but Miller could not find a place in any of its five teams.<ref name=w47/><ref name="p21"/> Joining the local [[Victorian Sub-District Cricket Association|sub-district]] cricket club [[Elsternwick]] instead, he did not get to bat or bowl in his first match, and was dropped to the second XI for his poor fielding.<ref name=Coleman/><ref name="p21"/><ref name=w48>Whitington, p. 48.</ref> Nevertheless, his team-mate, former [[Victorian Bushrangers|Victoria]] state player [[Hughie Carroll]], spotted Miller's talent and lured him to the rival [[Casey-South Melbourne Cricket Club|South Melbourne]] club.<ref name="p22"/><ref name=w48/> Miller began playing for South Melbourne the following season.<ref name="p22"/> It was at South Melbourne that Miller met [[Ian Johnson (cricketer)|Ian Johnson]] and [[Lindsay Hassett]], his future Australia captains. Miller scored 12 not out on debut, but observers felt he would succeed with a stronger physique;<ref name="p23">Perry, p. 23.</ref> Woodfull wrote in the 1936 school magazine, "Miller has Test possibilities".<ref name="p25">Perry, p. 25.</ref>
In March 1936, Miller played for South Melbourne against [[Carlton Cricket Club|Carlton]], captained by Woodfull. Miller came to the crease at 6/32.<ref name="p25"/> He guided his team to 141, putting on a stand of 65 with the last man and finishing with 61.<ref name="p26">Perry, p. 26.</ref><ref name=w49>Whitington, p. 49.</ref> The crowd gave Miller a standing ovation, and newspapers him compared him to Ponsford and [[Alan Kippax]].<ref name="p27">Perry, p. 27.</ref> The Carlton team presented him with a silver eggcup, "for sterling performance",<ref name="FabFarewell">{{cite news | title = Fab farewell for cricket legend Keith Miller | url = http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/10/20/1097951766524.html?from=storylhs | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | date = 20 October 2004 | accessdate =22 December 2007 }}</ref> which Woodfull presented to Miller during an algebra class.<ref name="p27"/> {{clear}}
==Debuts in Sheffield Shield and Victorian Football League== {{Infobox AFL biography | name = | image = Miller SK.jpg | caption = Miller, in the vertically striped jumper, playing for St Kilda | fullname = | nickname = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | originalteam = [[Brighton Football Club|Brighton]] | heightweight = 185 cm / 80 kg | position = [[Fullback (Australian rules football)|Full back]], [[full forward]] | guernsey = 27 (1940–41; 1946), 22 (1942) | years = 1940–42; 1946 | clubs = [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] | games(goals) = 50 (42) | sooyears = 1946 | sooteams = [[Victoria Australian rules football team|Victoria]] | soogames(goals) = 1 | statsend = 1946 }}
During 1936, Miller underwent a sudden growth spurt,<ref name="p25"/> of {{convert|28|cm|in|1}} in the year,<ref name="p29">Perry, p. 29.</ref> reaching {{convert|185|cm|ft|1}} in height. This thwarted his career as a jockey.<ref name=Coleman/><ref name=m64/><ref name=w49/> With his increased height and weight, he began to play football with more physical aggression.<ref name="p28">Perry, p. 28.</ref> At the end of 1936, he completed year 10 and quit high school, taking a position as a clerk.<ref name="p30">Perry, p. 30.</ref>
For the 1937–38 cricket season, Miller transferred to the [[VCA Colts cricket team|VCA Colts]],<ref name="p29"/> where he won the team's batting trophy for having the best average.<ref name=Coleman/><ref name="p30"/> At this stage, his method of playing was slow and steady accumulation of runs.<ref name="p31">Perry, p. 31.</ref> Late in the summer, he made his [[First-class cricket|first-class]] debut for Victoria and hit 181 against [[Tasmanian Tigers|Tasmania]] at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]].<ref name=w49/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/16/16497.html |publisher=[[CricketArchive]] |title=Victoria v Tasmania 1937–38 |accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref> In 1938–39, he rejoined South Melbourne and also played four further matches for Victoria, scoring 125 runs at an average of 25.00. However, he was yet to play in the [[Sheffield Shield]] competition, having appeared only in one-off matches.<ref name="p33"/><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Players/0/741/f_Batting_by_Season.html |publisher=[[CricketArchive]] |title=First-class batting and fielding in each season by KR Miller |accessdate=27 December 2007}}</ref>
During this period, Miller achieved more success as a footballer, following his brothers in joining the [[Brighton Football Club]] in the [[Victorian Football Association]] (VFA) in 1937.<ref name=Coleman/> A defender, Miller initially played on the [[Australian rules football positions#Half-Back Flank|half-back flank]] before moving to [[Fullback (Australian rules football)|full back]] during his third season, in 1939.<ref name="p33"/> At this stage, he lacked the strength to [[hip and shoulder]] his opponents and relied on his running ability and accurate kicking.<ref name="p33">Perry, p. 33.</ref>
Miller finally made his breakthrough in cricket in 1939–40, when he was selected to make his Sheffield Shield debut, against [[Southern Redbacks|South Australia]] at the [[Adelaide Oval]].<ref name="p35">Perry, p. 35.</ref> He managed just four and seven, batting at number five in the order.<ref name=w49/><ref name="p36"/><ref name="p37">Perry, p. 37.</ref> When Victoria fielded, Miller [[run out|ran out]] his future ''[[Australian cricket team in England in 1948|Invincibles]]'' captain [[Don Bradman]].<ref name="p36">Perry, p. 36.</ref><ref name=w50>Whitington, p. 50.</ref> One of Miller's teammates was [[Percy Beames]], who was also his manager at [[Vacuum Oil]].<ref name="p38"/> Miller scored 41 and 47 not out in his second match to hold his place. However, against [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]], Miller made a pair of 14s, having difficulties against [[leg spin]].<ref name="p38">Perry, p. 38.</ref> In the return match against South Australia, Miller took the initiative against leg-spinner [[Clarrie Grimmett]], aggressively advancing down the pitch and [[List of cricket terms#D|driving]]. Miller reached 108, his first [[Century (cricket)|century]] in Shield competition.<ref name=w50/><ref name="p39">Perry, p. 39.</ref><ref name="p40">Perry, p. 40.</ref> Apart from the century, Miller had a moderate season, ending with 298 runs at 29.80.<ref name="p43">Perry, p. 43.</ref>
In the Australian winter of 1940, Miller started his fourth season in the VFA. In a match against [[Coburg Tigers|Coburg]], he was assigned to [[fullback (Australian rules football)|nullify]] <!-- this wikilink is too obscure for the term --> the greatest forward of the era, [[Bob Pratt]].<ref name="p44">Perry, p. 44.</ref> Miller restricted Pratt to just one goal for the match and was named [[man of the match|best on ground]].<ref>Pratt had scored 678 goals in ten seasons for [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] in the [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] (VFL), the top tier of football, see Perry, p. 45.</ref> Scouts from top-tier [[Australian Football League|Victorian Football League]] (VFL) club [[St Kilda Football Club|St Kilda]] signed Miller on the spot.<ref name="p46">Perry, p. 46.</ref> In a match for St Kilda against [[Carlton Blues|Carlton]], Miller was [[wikt:king hit|king hit]] by his opponent [[Ron Cooper (Australian footballer)|Ron Cooper]] at the start of the match.<ref name="p47">Perry, p. 47.</ref><ref name="Main">Main, p. 269.</ref> When the teams next met, Miller [[hip and shoulder|shoulder bumped]] Cooper in the first minute, forcing him to leave the field.<ref name="p48">Perry, p. 48.</ref> St Kilda finished second-last that season.<ref name="p49">Perry, p. 49.</ref>
==War service== {{main|Military career of Keith Miller}} Miller's sporting career was interrupted by World War II. On 20 August 1940, he joined the [[Australian Army Reserve|Militia]] (army reserve), and was assigned to the 4th Reserve Motor Transport Company.<ref name="p49" /><ref name="ww2nom1">{{cite web | url = http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=A&veteranId=633547 | title = "Miller, Keith Ross" [Service Number V74626] | publisher = [[Department of Veterans' Affairs (Australia)|Department of Veterans' Affairs]] | accessdate =30 December 2007 }}</ref> In late September, Miller began his training. A non-conformist, he had the first of many clashes with authority in November, when he was fined for "using insulting language to a superior officer".<ref name="p49"/> Miller soon lived up to the traditional nickname of ''Dusty'', for anyone called Miller, with his tendency to be involved in fist fights and his rambunctious persona.<ref name="p50">Perry, p. 50.</ref>
During the summer of 1940–41, Miller was granted leave so that he could play interstate <!-- rm specify. They only had one-offs that season --> cricket. In a war-shortened season, Miller scored 140 runs at 28.00 and took his maiden first-class wicket.<ref name="p50"/><ref name=hr384>Harte, p. 384.</ref><ref name=c432>Coleman, p. 432.</ref><ref name=w53>Whitington, p. 53.</ref> The 1941 VFL season also went ahead. Miller played in defence and attack, depending on match conditions.<ref name="p51">Perry, p. 51.</ref> In 16 games, he kicked 28 goals,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://stats.afl.com.au/public/statistics/playerseasonlist/12/1941/playerseasonlist_12_1941.shtml?club_idIndex=13&season_idIndex=66 |publisher=[[Australian Football League]] |title=AFL statistics for St Kilda FC, season 1941 |accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref> including eight in one match.<ref name="p51"/> He again showed his disrespect for authority and reputation, striking his boss Beames—who played for [[Melbourne Football Club|Melbourne]]—with a raised elbow at the start of a match. Miller came second in St Kilda's best and fairest for the season.<ref name="p52">Perry, p. 52.</ref>
Miller's season ended early when he was recalled to duty. However, he had continued disciplinary problems,<ref name="p52"/> and left the Militia on 8 November 1941.<ref name="ww2nom1"/> Miller and a friend then attempted to join the [[Royal Australian Navy]]. When the navy rejected his friend, Miller tore up his own paperwork, left the recruiting office, and walked around the corner to the [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) recruiting office, where he enlisted.<ref name=p52/><ref>Miller, p. 38.</ref><ref name=w52>Whitington, p. 52.</ref>
Less than two months after the [[Imperial Japan|Japanese]] [[attack on Pearl Harbor]] in December 1941, Miller was called to active service.<ref name="ww2nom2">{{cite web | url = http://www.ww2roll.gov.au/Veteran.aspx?serviceId=R&veteranId=1057249 | title = "Miller, Keith Ross" [Service Number 410608] | publisher = [[Department of Veterans' Affairs (Australia)|Department of Veterans' Affairs]] | accessdate =30 December 2007 }}</ref> He trained at No. 4 Initial Training School, [[Victor Harbor]] in [[South Australia]],<ref name="p53">Perry, p. 53.</ref><ref name="p54">Perry, p. 54.</ref> and [[flight training|gained his wings]] in late 1942.<ref name=w53/><ref name="p55">Perry, p. 55.</ref> He played only one match during the 1942 football season, while posted in South Australia.<ref name=w53/><ref name="p55"/> In December, he was promoted to the rank of [[flight sergeant]] and,<ref name="p55"/> a month later, he sailed to Europe.<ref name="p56">Perry, p. 56.</ref> The journey included a stopover at a training camp in [[Boston]] in the United States, where Miller met his future wife Peg Wagner.<ref name=w53/><ref name="crossfire39">Miller, p. 39.</ref><ref name=c478>Coleman, p. 478.</ref> In March, he was deployed to [[Bournemouth]], in England, where he continued his training.<ref name="crossfire39"/><ref>Perry, pp. 59–61.</ref><ref name=w54>Whitington, p. 54.</ref>
[[File:RAAF cricket team 1943.jpg|thumb|left|The team for the first RAAF match. Miller is standing sixth from left.]] Miller was invited to join a [[Royal Australian Air Force cricket team|RAAF team]] in London.<ref name=p62/> The team was officially formed in preparation for the 1943 season and Miller's selection let to the first of many brushes with death: in April, while away with the team, some of his comrades were killed in a German air strike.<ref name="crossfire39"/><ref name="p62">Perry, p. 62.</ref><ref name="p64">Perry, p. 64.</ref><ref name=m63>Mallett, p. 63.</ref><ref name=h2>Haigh (1997), p. 2.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 54–55.</ref> Miller played his first match at [[Lord's]] against [[Plum Warner|Warner's XI]], a team that featured past, current and future [[England national cricket team|England]] players, including [[Bob Wyatt]], [[Gubby Allen]], [[Trevor Bailey]] and [[Alec Bedser]].<ref name="p65">Perry, p. 65.</ref><ref name="p66">Perry, p. 66.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/136/136523.html |title=Scorecard: Sir PF Warner's XI v Royal Australian Air Force|publisher=Cricket Archive}}</ref> Miller top-scored in the first innings with 45 and added 21 not out, with two sixes, in the second innings.<ref name="p67"/> The RAAF played eight matches that season and Miller's top score was 141 against [[Public School Wanderers]].<ref name="p67">Perry, p. 67.</ref> He went on to play for [[Dominions cricket team|Dominions]] against Warner's XI in August, scoring 32 and two.<ref name="p68">Perry, p. 68.</ref> The match marked the first meeting between Miller and his good friend, England batsman [[Denis Compton]] and his bowling began to attract media attention.<ref name="p69">Perry, p. 69.</ref> In the final match of the season at Lord's between the RAAF and the [[Royal Air Force]], Miller took 3/23 and scored 91.<ref name="p70">Perry, p. 70.</ref> The success of RAAF and Dominions that season, especially the attractive batting by Miller and [[Keith Carmody]],<ref name=hr385>Harte, p. 385.</ref> prompted Warner to begin planning for a "Test" series between the respective armed services of England and Australia.<ref>Pollard (1988), p. 359.</ref><ref name=w66>Whitington, p. 66.</ref>
By late 1943, Miller was based in [[Gloucestershire]]. One night, he threatened to punch his commanding officer, resulting in his being sentenced for insubordination to a three-week disciplinary course with hard labour.<ref name="p71">Perry, p. 71.</ref> In mid-November, he was posted to [[Ouston, Stamfordham|Ouston]] near [[Newcastle-upon-Tyne]] where he trained in the used of [[radar]].<ref name="p72">Perry, p. 72.</ref> During his stay there, Miller sustained a back injury during a wrestling match: the injury was to cause him recurring and enduring problems, particularly diminishing his ability to bowl.<ref name="p74">Perry, p. 74.</ref><ref name="p78">Perry, p. 78.</ref>
In 1944, Miller was again selected for the RAAF team. In a match against the British Civil Defence Services at Lord's in July, Miller reached his century just as a [[V-1 flying bomb]] landed nearby.<ref name="w66" /><ref name="p79">Perry, p. 79.</ref> In a match against an [[wiktionary:Scratch team|England XI]], Miller scored 85 in 100 minutes.<ref name="p80">Perry, p. 80.</ref> He then took match figures of 6/28 against the West of England at [[Bristol]].<ref name="p81">Perry, p. 81.</ref> [[File:De Havilland Mosquito-DK338-1942.jpg|thumb|right|A Mosquito, the type of aircraft piloted by Miller during World War II.]] After ten months of training, Miller was offered a commission as a [[pilot officer]],<ref name="p81"/> and was posted to 12 Advanced Flying Unit in [[Grantham]], [[Lincolnshire]] on 15 August 1944,<ref name="p82">Perry, p. 82.</ref> then moving on to [[Cranfield]], [[Bedfordshire]].<ref name="p83">Perry, p. 83.</ref> On a trip back to Ouston to visit former comrades, a night of drunken revelry saw Miller charged with eight offences and facing possible [[dishonourable discharge]].<ref name="p83"/> Luckily for Miller, his new Commanding Officer (CO) was his old CO from Ouston; Miller escaped with a fine.<ref name="p84">Perry, p. 84.</ref>
While training, Miller flew [[Bristol Beaufort|Beauforts]], [[Bristol Beaufighter|Beaufighters]] and [[De Havilland Mosquito|Mosquitos]]. He had another near death experience: mechanical problems forced him to make an emergency landing of his Beaufighter. The plane was repaired for use by others, but, on its next flight, the pilot was killed when the problem recurred.<ref name="p85">Perry, p. 85.</ref><ref name=w56>Whitington, p. 56.</ref> On another occasion, Miller avoided colliding with a hangar by centimetres.<ref name=w56/><ref name="p86"/> He then escaped death by skipping a social appointment; a [[V1 Flying Bomb|V1 bomb]] hit the venue and killed many of the patrons.<ref name="p86"/> In October, he went [[AWOL|AWL]] to watch a concert and was summarily discharged, but the CO revoked his decision after Miller agreed to play for his cricket team.<ref name="p86">Perry, p. 86.</ref> At the end of his officer training, Miller was sent aboard a [[Royal Navy]] destroyer as part of an exchange program between the forces. During a mission to [[Belgium]], the vessel fought a German [[U-boat]], which was sunk. Upon his return to England, Miller was promoted to [[flying officer]] on 4 November 1944.<ref name="p89">Perry, p. 89.</ref>
In March 1945, Miller was deployed to the RAF station at [[Great Massingham]] in [[Norfolk]], [[East Anglia]].<ref name="p93">Perry, p. 93.</ref> He was assigned to [[No. 169 Squadron RAF|169 Squadron]], flying Mosquito [[fighter-bomber]]s.<ref name="p94">Perry, p. 94.</ref> Miller's squadron took part in missions against targets on mainland Europe in April and May 1945. They attacked V-1 and [[V-2 rocket|V-2]] production and test launch sites on the island of [[Peenemünde]] in the [[North Sea]].<ref name="p95">Perry, p. 95.</ref><ref name=m62>Mallett, p. 62.</ref><ref name=w58>Whitington, p. 58.</ref> On 19 April, Miller took part in an attack on a German installation at [[Flensburg]] in [[Denmark]].<ref name="p96">Perry, p. 96.</ref> In May, his squadron was deployed in [[Operation Fire Bash]], to attack [[Westerland Airfield]] on the island of [[Sylt]].<ref name="p96"/><ref name="p97">Perry, p. 97.</ref> One of Miller's bombs failed to release and the load dangled from a wing. Miller was obliged to land the plane with the bomb still attached.<ref name=c478/><ref name="w58" /><ref name="p99">Perry, p. 99.</ref> Miller's next mission was delayed by poor weather, by which time Germany had surrendered.<ref>Perry, pp. 100–101.</ref> His commanding officer ordered him to fly air force personnel over Germany to view the results of Allied bombing. On one flight, Miller broke away from the flying formation and returned to base late because he wanted to fly over [[Bonn]], the birthplace of [[Beethoven]].<ref name=c478/><ref name=m62/><ref name="p102">Perry, p. 102.</ref>
Miller's wartime exploits were to give him a greater sense of perspective when he returned to the sports field. When asked many years later by [[Michael Parkinson]], about pressure in cricket, Miller responded with the famous quote:<ref name=p129/><ref name=730report/> "Pressure is a [[Messerschmitt Bf-109|Messerschmitt]] up your arse, playing cricket is not".<ref name="p129">Perry, p. 129.</ref><ref name="730report">{{cite news | first = Mark | last = Bannerman | title = Cricket legend Keith Miller remembered: 7.30 Report | url = http://www.abc.net.au/7.30/content/2004/s1218626.htm | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | date = 12 October 2004 | accessdate =14 December 2007 }}</ref>
===Victory Tests=== {{see also|Victory Tests}}
The end of the war prompted the belated start of the [[1945 English cricket season|1945 cricket season]]. Miller returned to Lord's and scored 50 for the RAAF against a British Empire XI.<ref name="p102" /> Warner had organised a celebratory series of matches between England and Australian servicemen, known as the [[Victory Tests]].<ref name="p103">Perry, p. 103.</ref> However, Australian cricket administrators would not accredit the three-day matches as Tests.<ref name="p103"/><ref name="p104"/><ref name=po366>Pollard (1988), p. 366.</ref><ref name=w65>Whitington, p. 65.</ref> England was close to full strength, so the [[Second Australian Imperial Force]] and the RAAF teams merged to form the [[Australian Services cricket team]] under the leadership of [[Warrant Officer]] Hassett.<ref name="p104">Perry, p. 104.</ref><ref name=w65/><ref name="p105">Perry, p. 105.</ref><ref name=po362>Pollard (1988), p. 362.</ref> The First Victory Test was at Lord's and was expected to usher in a new post-war era, which cricket watchers hoped would be more attractive to watch.<ref name="p105"/><ref name=po360>Pollard (1988), p. 360.</ref> England batted first and Miller bowled his Great Massingham colleague [[Bill Edrich]] to end with 1/11 and precipitate an English collapse.<ref name=po362/><ref name="p106">Perry, p. 106.</ref><ref name=w72>Whitington, p. 72.</ref> Miller came to the crease at and helped Australia take the lead, before cutting loose, eventually finishing with 105 in 210 minutes.<ref name="p107">Perry, p. 107.</ref><ref>Pollard (1988), pp. 362–363.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 72–73.</ref> ''[[The Times]]'' opined that his innings was "as good a century as has been seen at Lord's in many a long day".<ref name="p108">Perry, p. 108.</ref> Australia went on to win by six wickets.<ref name="p110">Perry, p. 110.</ref><ref name=h386>Harte, p. 386.</ref><ref name=po363>Pollard (1988), p. 363.</ref><ref name=h387>Harte, p. 387.</ref><ref name=w73>Whitington, p. 73.</ref>
Miller warmed up for the Second Victory Test by top-scoring for the RAAF against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] and the RAF.<ref name="p111">Perry, p. 111.</ref> In the Test, played at [[Bramall Lane]], Miller went wicketless and scored 17 in the first innings.<ref name="p111"/><ref name="p112">Perry, p. 112.</ref><ref name=w76>Whitington, p. 76.</ref><ref name=po364>Pollard (1988), p. 364.</ref> In the second innings, Miller bowled a fierce spell,<ref name=h387/> hitting Test world record holder [[Len Hutton]] and [[Cyril Washbrook]] on the arm and head respectively, provoking an angry crowd reaction.<ref name="po364" /><ref name="p113">Perry, p. 113.</ref><ref name=m73>Mallett, p. 73.</ref> At the time, Miller had a leisurely attitude towards bowling, so his success led to calls for him to start taking it seriously, instead of simply jogging in and releasing the ball.<ref name="m73"/> Despite this, Australia lost the match.<ref name="m73"/><ref name="p114">Perry, p. 114.</ref><ref name=w77>Whitington, p. 77.</ref>
In the meantime, Miller earned the further ire of his CO by flying unauthorised leisure flights. Not wanting to fly tour flights over Germany, Miller lodged bogus reports saying that the Mosquitoes were malfunctioning, causing unnecessary maintenance work.<ref>Perry, pp. 116–117.</ref> Thus, the CO ordered Miller to take his plane instead, which caught fire. With one functional engine, Miller came back to the air base and bellylanded.<ref name="w58"/> The plane broke apart and caught fire, but Miller escaped physical injury and was playing sport an hour later.<ref name="w58"/><ref>Perry, pp. 118–119.</ref><ref name=m65>Mallett, p. 65.</ref>
[[File:Miller bowls Hutton.jpg|thumb|[[Len Hutton]]'s off stump has just been knocked out by Miller during the Third Victory Test.]] The next day, Miller headed to Lord's to play for the RAAF against the South of England. Chasing 208, Miller scored an unbeaten 78 in 95 minutes, but rain washed out the match.<ref name=h387/><ref name="p120">Perry, p. 120.</ref> In the first innings of Third Victory Test at Lord's,<ref name="p121">Perry, p. 121.</ref> when finally called upon to bowl, Miller measured out a run-up<ref name=po365>Pollard (1988), p. 365.</ref><ref name=w78>Whitington, p. 78.</ref> and removed [[John Dewes]], [[Donald Carr]] and Hutton, all bowled. He ended with 3/44.<ref name=po365/><ref name=w78/><ref>Perry, pp. 122–123.</ref> Miller was rewarded with the new ball in the second innings. He removed Dewes, Edrich and [[Dick Pollard]] to end with 3/42.<ref name="p124"/> This left Australia a target of 225. Miller saw Australia to the target, unbeaten on 71.<ref name="m73"/><ref name=po365/><ref name=w78/><ref name="p124">Perry, p. 124.</ref><ref name="p125">Perry, p. 125.</ref> In the Fourth Test, again at Lord's, Miller scored 118 in the first innings,<ref name=po365/><ref name="p126">Perry, p. 126.</ref><ref name=h388>Harte, p. 388.</ref><ref name=w79>Whitington, p. 79.</ref> before an unbeaten 25 in the second innings ensured a draw.<ref name=po365/><ref name="p127">Perry, p. 127.</ref> The tremendous public reception of the Victory Tests resulted in a fifth match being added to the schedule.<ref name="p128">Perry, p. 128.</ref>
In the meantime Japan had surrendered, and No. 169 Squadron was disbanded. Miller had spent around 550 hours in the air with the RAF, to which his RAAF unit had been seconded. He was awarded the [[1939-1945 Star|1939–45 Star]], [[France and Germany Star]], [[Defence Medal (United Kingdom)|Defence Medal]], [[War Medal 1939–1945]] and [[Australia Service Medal 1939-45|Australia Service Medal 1939–45]].<ref name="p128"/>
In the Fifth Victory Test, under overcast conditions against a swinging and seaming ball, Miller struck 14 from his first over and finished 77 not out, in a display that featured strong cutting and driving.<ref name=po366/><ref name=h388/><ref name=w79/> Australia could manage only 173, and England were on top.<ref>Perry, pp. 130–131.</ref> Miller took one wicket with the ball but managed only four in the second innings as England won, to square the series 2–2.<ref>Perry, pp. 131–132.</ref> Hassett wrote at the end of the series that "This is cricket as it should be... let's have no more talk of "war" in cricket".<ref name="p132"/> Miller topped the batting averages for the series, with 443 runs at 63.28. His aggregate exceeded those of Hammond and Hutton, and he also took 10 wickets at 27.70.<ref name="p132"/> Of Miller's batting, Hassett said that "as a strokeplayer he is second to none",<ref name="p132">Perry, p. 132.</ref><ref name=m74>Mallett, p. 74.</ref><ref name=po367/> and his performance earned comparisons to [[Jack Gregory (cricketer)|Jack Gregory]], who had a similar breakthrough after [[World War I]].<ref name=w79/>
The last big match of the season was a one-off match at Lord's between England and "Dominions", a [[scratch team]] of players from the British Commonwealth. Miller managed 26 in the Dominions' first innings of 307,<ref name="p1323">Perry, pp. 132–133.</ref> before cutting loose in the second innings. After settling in, he hit [[Eric Hollies]] for two sixes, including one that hit the top of the roof.<ref name=m64/><ref name=po367/><ref name=w81>Whitington, p. 81.</ref> The next day, he registered his century in 115 minutes, clouting another five balls over the boundary in the morning session. In one 35-minute passage of play, he and [[Learie Constantine]] added 91 runs, before Miller departed for 185, made in just 165 minutes.<ref name="p1323"/> The Dominions went on to win by 45 runs in a match described by ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack|Wisden]]'' as "one of the finest ever seen".<ref name="p135"/> Commenting on Miller' innings, [[R. C. Robertson-Glasgow|Robertson-Glasgow]] said "From the moment he takes guard he plays each ball just that much below its supposed merits that scratches a bowler's pride".<ref name="p134">Perry, p. 134.</ref> Miller had enjoyed his visit to the home of cricket. In eight innings at Lord's for the season, he had scored 568 runs at 94.68, with three centuries.<ref name="p135">Perry, p. 135.</ref>
The season ended with a few more matches against English counties. Miller struck aggressive half-centuries in wins against [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire]] and Leveson-Gower's XI.<ref>Perry, pp. 136–137.</ref><ref name=h389>Harte, p. 389.</ref><ref name=w82>Whitington, p. 82.</ref> In first-class matches, Miller had scored 725 runs at 72.50 for the season, finishing second in both averages and aggregates.<ref name="p137">Perry, p. 137.</ref> The success of the Australian Services prompted a fundraising tour of India and [[Ceylon]] on their return to Australia.<ref name=po367>Pollard (1988), p. 367.</ref><ref name=h389/><ref name="p138">Perry, p. 138.</ref>
===Services tour of India=== Miller, the vice-captain, almost missed the trip to India after turning up late for the voyage.<ref name="p139">Perry, p. 139.</ref> On arrival in India, Miller scored 46 in a draw against [[North Zone cricket team|North Zone]].<ref name="p141">Perry, p. 141.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 86–89.</ref> Miller then captained the Australians in a match against [[West Zone cricket team|West Zone]] in [[Bombay]], top-scoring with 106 in a high-scoring draw.<ref name="p142">Perry, p. 142.</ref><ref name=po368>Pollard (1988), p. 368.</ref> In a match against [[India national cricket team|India]], Miller took two wickets.<ref name="p143">Perry, p. 153.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 92–93.</ref> At this point, with most of the team suffering from dysentery and the leadership not permitting the team to travel by air,<ref name="w94"/> some of the RAAF personnel felt that Hassett should be removed from the captaincy, with Miller as one of the candidates to replace him.<ref name=w94>Whitington, p. 94.</ref><ref name=po369>Pollard (1988), p. 369.</ref> This would have increased his prospects of leading Australia.<ref>Perry, pp. 145–146.</ref> Miller refused to plot against Hassett and the dispute ended when a RAAF plane was acquired to transport the team.<ref name="w94" /><ref name=po369/><ref name="p146">Perry, p. 146.</ref>
[[File:Compton Miller.jpg|thumb|left|Compton (l) and Miller (r)]]
The team played [[East Zone cricket team|East Zone]] in [[Calcutta]] as the city was in the grip of deadly pro-independence riots.<ref name="p147">Perry, p. 147.</ref> Miller's friend [[Denis Compton]] was batting for East Zone when rioters invaded the pitch. Their leader ran up to Compton and said: "Mr Compton, you very good player, but you must stop".<ref name=po369/><ref name="p148">Perry, p. 148.</ref><ref name="CrossfireCompton">{{cite book |last=Miller |first=Keith |title=Cricket Crossfire |year= 1956 |publisher=Oldbourne Press |location=London |page= 77. }}</ref><ref name=w95>Whitington, p. 95.</ref> In later years, whenever Miller opposed Compton, he would quote this remark when Compton came to the [[Crease (cricket)|crease]].<ref name="p149"/> In 2005, the [[England and Wales Cricket Board|ECB]] and [[Cricket Australia]] decided that the player adjudged the Player of the Series in [[the Ashes]] would be awarded the [[Compton–Miller Medal]], recognising their friendship and rivalry.<ref name="ECB">{{cite web | url = http://www.channel4.com/sport/cricket/news/nr_6598.html | title = The Compton-Miller medal is born | publisher = [[Channel 4]] | date = 20 July 2005 | accessdate =27 December 2007 }}</ref>
In the second match against India, Services were 2/250 in response to India's 386 when Miller came in and scored 82, including four sixes in five balls.<ref name="p149">Perry, p. 149.</ref><ref name="p150">Perry, p. 150.</ref><ref name=w97>Whitington, p. 97.</ref><ref name=h390>Harte, p. 390.</ref> The match ended in a draw and Miller aggravating an injury.<ref name=w97/><ref name=po370>Pollard (1988), p. 370.</ref> Miller took 3/19 against [[South Zone cricket team|South Zone]] in [[Chennai|Madras]], the Australians' only win in India. He failed with the bat in the third and final match against India, scoring two and seven, but he took 2/60 in the first innings as India took the series 1–0.<ref name="p151"/> Overall, Miller had a disappointing series in the international matches, with 107 runs at 26.25 and four wickets at 40.50.<ref name="p151">Perry, p. 151.</ref> Australia's final match was in [[Colombo]] against an All Ceylon team. Miller scored 132 as Australia won by an innings.<ref name=po370/><ref name="p151"/><ref name=h391>Harte, p. 391.</ref>
===Services in Australia=== [[File:Miller and Pepper.jpg|thumb|upright|Miller walks out to bat with Services teammate [[Cec Pepper]].]] Upon returning to Australia, Hassett's men were assigned to play a further six first-class matches against the state teams. The fixtures were meant to revive cricket and were also used as a lead-up to the international tour to [[New Zealand]] in March 1946.<ref name=po369/><ref name=h391/><ref name="p157">Perry, p. 157.</ref> Miller started his campaign with 80 against [[Western Warriors|Western Australia]].<ref name="p157"/><ref name=po371>Pollard (1988), p. 371.</ref> He finally returned to Melbourne in January, before taking on Victoria.<ref name="p160">Perry, p. 160.</ref> Miller top-scored in both innings with 37 and 59 in an innings defeat.<ref name="p161">Perry, p. 161.</ref><ref name=w104>Whitington, p. 104.</ref><ref name=po372>Pollard (1988), p. 372.</ref>
Miller had another difficult time against [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]], as the state side made 7/551 and Miller went wicketless.<ref name="p161"/><ref name=po372/> When the servicemen batted, they faced an attack featuring leading leg spinner [[Bill O'Reilly (cricketer)|Bill O'Reilly]] and paceman [[Ray Lindwall]], the fastest in Australia.<ref name=po372/><ref name="p162">Perry, p. 162.</ref><ref name=w101>Whitington, p. 101.</ref> Miller was on 74 as Services limped to 9/171. With only one partner left, Miller attacked, scoring 31 of the last 33 runs to end unbeaten on 105, and earning plaudits among cricket pundits on Australian soil.<ref name=h391/><ref name="p162"/><ref name=w105>Whitington, p. 105.</ref> Former leading Test batsman [[Alan Kippax]] opined that "Australia has unearthed a new champion",<ref name="p163">Perry, p. 163.</ref> while O'Reilly said that Miller's century was "one of the best hundreds ever got against me".<ref name="p163"/> Miller compiled 46 in the second innings as the Servicemen fell to another innings defeat. Miller finished the season with 4/49 against [[Queensland Bulls|Queensland]] and a pair of fifties against Tasmania.<ref name="p163"/><ref name=w106>Whitington, p. 106.</ref>
==Test career==
===Test debut===
At the end of the season, Miller was selected for the New Zealand tour, under the captaincy of Queensland's [[Bill Brown (cricketer)|Bill Brown]].<ref name="p166">Perry, p. 166.</ref><ref name=h393>Harte, p. 393.</ref> Miller started the tour well, top-scoring with 139 against [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]].<ref name=h393/><ref name="p167">Perry, p. 167.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 107–108.</ref> Along with seven other debutants,<ref name="onetest">{{cite web|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62661.html|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=28 November 2007|title=Only Test: New Zealand vs Australia at Wellington, March 29–30, 1946}}</ref> Miller made his test debut in the match against [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] at the [[Basin Reserve]] in [[Wellington]], a match that was retrospectively accorded Test status in 1948.<ref name="p168">Perry, p. 168.</ref> On a [[sticky wicket]], New Zealand won the toss and batted. Miller was not required to bowl in the first innings as O'Reilly and [[Ernie Toshack]] skittled the home side for just 42.<ref name="p168"/><ref name=testlist/> Australia made 8/199 with Miller scoring 30. He was allowed to take the new ball in the second innings,<ref name="p169">Perry, p. 169.</ref> taking 2/6 in six overs before a flare-up of his back injury forced him to be removed from the attack. Australia bowled their hosts out for 54, securing an innings victory.<ref name=h393/><ref name="p170">Perry, p. 170.</ref>
Despite the scare over his back complaint, Miller returned from New Zealand to play in the 1946 season, which turned out to be his last season in the VFL; St Kilda's finished second-last.<ref name="p174">Perry, p. 174.</ref> Miller played with more aggression than during his pre-war years and his high leaping [[Mark (Australian rules football)|marks]] were a noted feature of a season that saw him chosen to represent Victoria against South Australia.<ref name=p175/> Miller thus became one of the few players to play at the highest levels of both cricket and Australian rules football.<ref name="p175">Perry, p. 175.</ref>
[[File:Miller V.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Miller sporting a cut nose during a football match]] Miller was discharged from the RAAF on 26 June 1946,<ref name="p175"/> and returned to his job at Vacuum Oil. Miller resented the fact that many of his colleagues had avoided the hazards of war and moved steadily up the ladder and regarded his job as demeaning.<ref name="p176">Perry, p. 176.</ref><ref name=w108>Whitington, p. 108.</ref> Under such circumstances, Miller contemplated quitting Australian cricket and accepting a professional contract with [[Rawtenstall Cricket Club|Rawtenstall]] in the [[Lancashire League (cricket)|Lancashire League]], valued at £1,000 per year,<ref name=w110>Whitington, p. 110.</ref> for three seasons. With advertising and commercial commitments likely to triple this figure, playing in England would have been approximately ten times more lucrative than continuing in Australia.<ref name="p176"/> However, Miller was worried that his impulsive style would be curtailed by the pressures of professionalism. At that time, the Board of Control's policy stipulated that any player that signed with a professional league in England could not represent Australia.<ref name="p180">Perry, p. 180.</ref> Miller's contract would see him in England until he was 30, effectively ending his career for Australia. Furthermore, it would have prevented him from playing Australian football during the winter.<ref name="p177">Perry, p. 177</ref> Miller weighed it up and opted to sign the contract that tied him to Rawtenstall, with his duties to start with the onset of the English season in April 1947.<ref name="p178">Perry, p. 178.</ref>
In the meantime, Miller had the upcoming Test series against England in 1946–47 to look forward to. He therefore approached his employers for two months leave so that he could travel to the United States to marry Wagner, which would allow him time to return in preparation for the international series. Vacuum Oil refused, so, with the comfort of job security in England, Miller resigned.<ref name="p178"/><ref name=w109>Whitington, p. 109.</ref>
Miller left Australia at the end of the football season in late August, amid press speculation that he might not return.<ref name="p179">Perry, p. 179.</ref> He was reunited in Boston with Wagner after more than three years of separation and they married on 21 September 1946. Miller and his new bride returned to Australia in November.<ref name=p180/><ref name="w109"/> In the meantime, his contract with Rawtenstall became public knowledge and he was threatened with his Test career being terminated if he began playing for the English team.<ref name=p180/>
===First Ashes series=== {{main|Keith Miller in the 1946-47 Australian cricket season}} Miller's season started amid ongoing speculation about whether he would fulfil his contract with Rawtenstall. Miller remained silent.<ref name="p182">Perry, p. 182.</ref> In a Shield match in front of Bradman at the [[Adelaide Oval]], Miller struck form with 188 and 2/32 with the ball.<ref name="w109" /><ref name="p184">Perry, p. 184.</ref><ref name=sc1>{{cite web|publisher=[[CricketArchive]]|accessdate=12 December 2008|url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/17/17890.html|title=South Australia v Victoria Sheffield Shield 1946/47}}</ref> ''Wisden'' said Miller's innings was "one of the finest batting displays ever seen at Adelaide".<ref name=a115>Armstrong, p. 115.</ref> Bradman saw Miller as a top-order batsman and as the new ball partner for Lindwall. Although Miller was a reluctant bowler, Bradman felt that he was crucial to his strategy of attacking England's strong batting line-up with express pace.<ref name="p185">Perry, p. 185.</ref> <!-- controversy over his contract - what happened? -->
Miller made his Ashes debut in the [[1946-47 Ashes series#First Test – Brisbane|First Test in Brisbane]]. Bradman opted for six front-line bowlers, with Miller as high as number five in the batting order.<ref name="p186">Perry, p. 186.</ref> Australia batted first, with Miller coming in at 3/322.<ref name=po381>Pollard (1988), p. 381.</ref> He played aggressively to reach his fifty in just 80 minutes, striking a six onto the roof of the members' stand at [[long on]], the biggest hit at the ground at the time,<ref name=p188/> before being trapped [[leg before wicket]] by [[Doug Wright (cricketer)|Doug Wright]] for 79 as Australia made 645.<ref name="p188">Perry, p. 188.</ref><ref name=w112>Whitington, p. 112.</ref> Miller was given the new ball along with Lindwall and he took his first Ashes wicket, bowling Hutton as England closed at 1/21. The following day, the pitch had turned into a [[sticky wicket]] following a heavy tropical storm.<ref name=po381/> Miller bowled off breaks at medium pace and mixed in a large amount of [[bouncer (cricket)|bouncers]].<ref name="p189">Perry, p. 189.</ref> <!-- medium pace bouncers? --> On the unpredictable surface, Edrich was struck around 40 times on the body. Miller cut through the English top order, removing Edrich, Washbrook, Compton and [[Jack Ikin]] on the fourth morning, finishing with 7/60 as England made 141 and were forced to [[follow on]]. Miller took two wickets, including the dismissal of Hutton with first ball of the second innings as England fell to defeat by an innings and 334 runs and Miller had match figures of 9/77.<ref name="testlist">{{cite web|url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/statsguru/engine/player/6612.html?class=1;template=results;type=allround;view=innings|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|title=Statsguru – KR Miller – Test matches – All-round analysis|accessdate=9 July 2008}}</ref><ref name="p191">Perry, p. 191.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 112–113.</ref>
During that first Test, an incident occurred, coloured by Miller's wartime service, that soured his relationship with Bradman and his feelings towards Test cricket. [[Michael Parkinson]] described it as follows: <blockquote>Keith Miller was deeply affected by the Second World War. It changed him ... In the first post-war Ashes Test ... England were caught on a sticky ... [and] Bill Edrich came in. He'd had a serious war and he survived and Miller thought, 'He's my old Services mate. The last thing he wants after five years' war is to be flattened by a cricket ball, so I eased up. Bradman came up to me and said, 'Don't slow down, Keith. Bowl quicker.' That remark put me off Test cricket. Never felt the same way about it after that.'<ref>Quoted in ''Wisden'' 2003, p. 1671.</ref></blockquote>
In the [[1946-47 Ashes series#Second Test – Sydney|Second Test in Sydney]]. Miller had a quiet match, scoring 40 and taking one wicket on a spin-friendly pitch as Australia secured another innings victory,<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p192">Perry, p. 192.</ref><ref name=h397>Harte, p. 397.</ref><ref name=po384>Pollard (1988), p. 384.</ref><ref name=w116>Whitington, p. 116.</ref> but showed he was in prime batting form when he returned to the Sheffield Shield. Playing against New South Wales, he hammered three sixes in one over and made 153 of a 271-run partnership with [[Merv Harvey]] in just over three hours, setting up an innings victory. [[Bill Ponsford]] said that it was the hardest hitting he had ever seen.<ref name=w110/><ref name="p194">Perry, p. 194.</ref><ref name=nsw1>{{cite web| publisher=[[CricketArchive]]|title=Victoria v New South Wales Sheffield Shield 1946/47|url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/17/17923.html|accessdate=12 December 2008}}</ref> The Third Test was Miller's first in his home town. He had a mediocre game in a drawn match, scoring 33 and 34, and taking two wickets.<ref>Perry, pp. 195–196.</ref>
Off the pitch, Miller privately decided that he would not honour his Rawtenstall contract.<ref name=p197/> He secretly accepted an offer to relocate to Sydney to work as a liquor salesman and play cricket.<ref name="p197">Perry, p. 197.</ref> Back in a good frame of mind for the Fourth Test in Adelaide, Miller took one wicket in each innings,<ref name="testlist"/> but he shone with the bat. After England had made 460, Miller came in at 3/207, and was 23 not out by the close of the second day.<ref name="p198"/> He hit the first ball of the next day for six,<ref name=w132>Whitington, p. 132.</ref> and accumulated 67 runs in the opening 71 minutes, to reach his maiden Test century. The Englishmen utilised [[leg theory]] to prevent easy scoring, but as the tail began to be dismissed, Miller accelerated, launching drives into the crowd, despite the presence of four men on the [[boundary (cricket)|fence]]. Miller ended unbeaten on 141 but the match petered out into a high-scoring draw.<ref name="p198">Perry, p. 198.</ref><ref name=po387>Pollard (1988), p. 387.</ref> Before the last Test, Miller played for Victoria against England, taking 4/65.<ref name="p199">Perry, p. 199.</ref>
The [[1946-47 Ashes series#Fifth Test – Sydney|Fifth Test]]. saw Miller take a wicket in each innings. Australia were left a target of 214 runs on a wearing wicket. Wright beat Miller with three consecutive leg breaks, but Miller survived and struck consecutive boundaries on the way to reaching the target.<ref name="p201">Perry, p. 201.</ref><ref>Pollard (1988), pp. 388–389.</ref><ref name=h399>Harte, p. 399.</ref><ref name=w136>Whitington, p. 136.</ref> Australia had taken the series 3–0; Miller scored 384 runs at 76.80 and took 16 wickets at 20.88, which placed him second in both the batting and bowling averages, to Bradman and Lindwall respectively.<ref name="p201"/> Nevertheless, Miller had become disillusioned with Bradman's ruthless mentality. Miller was impulsive and cared little for records or ruthlessly dominating his opponents, preferring to play in a flamboyant manner in close contests.<ref name="p193">Perry, p. 193.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 114–119.</ref>
For the 1947–48 Australian season, Miller transferred to [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales (NSW)]], for whom he played the remainder of his Sheffield Shield career. He also represented the New South Wales interstate football team at the [[1947 Hobart Carnival]], as vice captain.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://army.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4619/history/story01.htm|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=23 November 2008|title=Air Force News – A rich innings}}</ref> This made him one of the few players to play both football and cricket for two states.<ref name=Coleman/>
Miller had a light workload in the 1947–48 home Test series against [[India national cricket team|India]],<ref name="p219">Perry, p. 219.</ref> who were on their first tour to Australia.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://stats.cricinfo.com/india/engine/records/team/series_results.html?class=1;id=6;type=team| accessdate =24 September 2008| publisher = ESPNcricinfo| title = Series results – India – Test matches}}</ref> India were well beaten, losing 4–0, three of the four defeats by an innings.<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://content-www.cricinfo.com/india/engine/series/60340.html| title = India in Australia Test Series, 1947/48| publisher = ESPNcricinfo| accessdate =24 September 2008}}</ref> Miller was required to bat just once in each Test, accumulating 185 runs at 37.00, including two half-centuries,<ref name="testlist"/> while the batsmen ahead of him plundered the bowling.<ref name="p219"/> His bowling duties were also light; his 72 overs yielded nine wickets at 24.78.<ref name="testlist"/> In both his fifties, Miller featured in century partnerships with his partners, respectively Bradman and Hassett in the First and Fourth test respectively.<ref name=po394>Pollard (1988), p. 394.</ref> His 58 in the First Test at Brisbane featured many big hits.<ref name=po393>Pollard (1988), p. 393.</ref>
===''Invincibles'' tour=== {{main|Keith Miller with the Australian cricket team in England in 1948}} {{see also|Australian cricket team in England in 1948|1948 Ashes series}} [[Donald Bradman]]'s [[Australian cricket team in England in 1948|1948 touring party to England]] has become known to cricket history as ''The Invincibles'', remaining undefeated in its 31 matches.<ref name=p255>Perry, p. 255.</ref> Miller started the tour strongly, scoring a hard-hitting 50 not out against [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]],<ref>Fingleton, p. 47.</ref><ref name=worcs>{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18403.html |title = Worcestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate =18 December 2008}}</ref> and an unbeaten 202 against [[Leicestershire County Cricket Club|Leicestershire]].<ref name="p224">Perry, p. 224.</ref><ref name=f50>Fingleton, p. 50.</ref><ref name=leics>{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18406.html |title = Leicestershire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate =26 December 2007}}</ref> In the next match against [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club|Yorkshire]], Miller took 6/42, including the prized wicket of [[Leonard Hutton|Hutton]], as the home team were demolished for just 71.<ref name=p225/> Australia then struggled to 101, including a counterattacking 34 from Miller, who took 3/49 in the second innings in an Australian victory.<ref name="p225">Perry, p. 225.</ref><ref name=y>{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18412.html |title = Yorkshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate =26 December 2007}}</ref><ref>Fingleton, pp. 53–57.</ref>
In a later match, against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], Miller was involved in a famous incident that is frequently cited when his character is discussed; it also spotlighted his differences with Bradman. On a day when the Australians set a world-record of 721 runs in a single day,<ref name="p227">Perry, p. 227.</ref><ref name=m69>Mallett, p. 69.</ref> Miller came to the crease with his side already dominating, with the score 2/364. He deliberately allowed himself to be [[bowled]] first ball, much to Bradman's displeasure, in a protest against the one-sided nature of the contest.<ref name="p226">Perry, p. 226.</ref><ref name=f67>Fingleton, p. 67.</ref>
Australia then took on [[Marylebone Cricket Club|the MCC]] at [[Lord's]]; effectively a dress rehearsal for the Tests as many of England's Test players were in the MCC team.<ref name="p228">Perry, p. 228.</ref> Miller scored 163 in 250 minutes, hitting 20 fours and three sixes in another innings win.<ref name="p228"/><ref>Fingleton, p. 73.</ref> Soon after, Rawtenstall dropped the contract dispute with Miller after being offered compensation.<ref name="p230">Perry, p. 230.</ref>
Following another good all-round performance against [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]], top-scoring in the first innings and taking 5/25 in the second,<ref name="p232">Perry, pp. 232–233.</ref><ref name=hants>{{cite web |url = http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18473.html |title = Hampshire v Australians |publisher = [[CricketArchive]] |accessdate =26 December 2007}}</ref> Miller went into the First Test (at [[Trent Bridge]]) in fine form. On the first morning, Miller bowled Hutton and Compton on his way to 3/38, helping Australia dismiss England cheaply and seize the initiative. Miller scored a duck, but Australia took a 344-run lead on the first innings.<ref name="p235">Perry, p. 235.</ref><ref name="report1">{{Cite web|title= First Test Match England v Australia|work= [[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]|year=1949|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152894.html|accessdate=2 July 2008|publisher=[[Wisden]]}}</ref><ref>Fingleton, pp. 83–87.</ref> In the second innings, he resumed his battle with Hutton and Compton, delivering five bouncers in the last over of the day.<ref name="p235"/> The batsmen survived, but Miller received a hostile reaction from the crowd.<ref name=f98>Fingleton, p. 98.</ref> The next day, he bowled Hutton for 74 and then [[bouncer (cricket)|bounced]] Compton, causing him to [[hit wicket|fall onto his stumps]] for 184.<ref name="report1"/><ref>Fingleton, pp. 99–105.</ref> Australia won by eight wickets,<ref>Perry, pp. 236–238.</ref> Miller ending with 4/125 for the second innings and 7/163 for the match.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p238">Perry, p. 238.</ref>
Miller was unfit to bowl during the Second Test at Lord's.<ref name="p239">Perry, p. 239.</ref> During England's first innings, Bradman threw Miller the ball, hoping that he would reverse his decision not to bowl. Miller refused and returned the ball, citing his back. Miller's action generated news headlines, with journalists believing that he had disobeyed Bradman.<ref name="m73" /><ref name="p240"/>
As a batsman, Miller was out for four in the first innings, not offering a shot to an [[inswinger]].<ref name="p240">Perry, p. 240.</ref> In the second innings, Miller's first ball was a [[hat-trick#Cricket|hat-trick ball]] from English captain [[Norman Yardley]]; he survived a loud [[leg before wicket]] appeal and then hit a six into the grandstand, on his way to 74.<ref>Fingleton, pp. 120–121.</ref> Australia declared at 7/460, 595 runs ahead.<ref name="p241">Perry, p. 241.</ref> Miller took three catches as Australia won by 409 runs.<ref>Perry, pp. 240–241.</ref><ref name=f112>Fingleton, p. 112.</ref>
After the Lord's Test, Miller enjoyed a night out and returned to the team hotel after daybreak the next morning.<ref name="p242">Perry, p. 242.</ref> Australia were due to play [[Surrey County Cricket Club|Surrey]] at [[The Oval]] that day. With Australia in the field, Bradman sent Miller to the [[Cricket terminology#F|fine leg]] boundary as a punishment—between overs, he was forced to walk the length of the field. One of the spectators felt sorry for Miller and lent him his bicycle, which Miller used to cycle around the circumference of the ground.<ref name="p242"/>
The efforts of Miller and Lindwall against Hutton had led the English selectors to drop the Yorkshireman for the Third Test. The Australians were surprised by the move and thought that it was a bad move by their opponents.<ref>Perry, pp. 242–243.</ref><ref>Fingleton, pp. 126–132.</ref> Miller had a quiet Third Test at [[Old Trafford Cricket Ground|Old Trafford]], taking one wicket and scoring 31 as the match ended in a draw.<ref name="testlist"/> In a rain-shortened match, Miller again earned the ire of the crowd, after aiming a series of bouncers at Edrich, in apparent retaliation to the Englishman's bouncing of Lindwall.<ref name="p243">Perry, p. 243.</ref><ref>Fingleton, pp. 141–145.</ref> He struck Edrich on the body before Bradman ordered him to stop.<ref name="p243" /><ref name="p244">Perry, p. 244.</ref>
The teams moved to [[Headingley Stadium#Headingley Carnegie Cricket Ground|Headingley]] for the Fourth Test at [[Leeds]]. Hutton had been recalled and the home team batted first. England tallied 496 and Miller took 1/43.<ref>Fingleton, pp. 145–151.</ref> In reply, Australia were struggling at 3/68 in reply on the third morning. [[Neil Harvey]], playing his first Ashes Test, joined Miller at the crease.<ref name="p245">Perry, p. 245.</ref> The pair launched a counterattack, with Miller taking the lead. He hoisted [[Jim Laker]]'s first ball over square leg for six. Miller struck consecutive sixes over long off and the [[List of cricket terms#S|sightscreen]] respectively. This allowed Australia to seize the initiative; Harvey joined in and hit consecutive boundaries against Laker. Miller then lifted another six over [[Fielding (cricket)#Fielding position names and locations|long off]], and another over [[Fielding (cricket)#Fielding position names and locations|long on]] from [[Norman Yardley]]. He was dismissed for 58 attempting another six.<ref name="p246">Perry, p. 246.</ref><ref name=f162>Fingleton, p. 162.</ref><ref name=f163>Fingleton, p. 163.</ref> The partnership had yielded 121 runs in only 90 minutes, and was described by Wisden as a "hurricane".<ref>{{cite web|title= Wisden 1954 – Neil Harvey|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/australia/content/story/154608.html| publisher=[[Wisden]]|year=1954|accessdate=6 June 2007}}</ref> [[John Arlott]] described the innings as the most memorable that he had witnessed.<ref name="p246"/> He said "Miller played like an emperor ... Every stroke would have been memorable but each one had bettered its predecessor".<ref name="p247">Perry, p. 247.</ref> [[Jack Fingleton]] said that he had never "known a more enjoyable hour" of "delectable cricket".<ref>Fingleton, pp. 162–163.</ref> The momentum swung and Australia finished at 457 on the fourth day, having added almost 396 in one day's play.<ref name="p247"/><ref name="sco4">{{cite web| title = 4th Test England v Australia at Leeds July 22–27, 1948|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62688.html|publisher= [[ESPNcricinfo]]|accessdate=12 December 2007}}</ref> Miller took 1/53 in the second innings as Australia were set a world record chase of 404 on the final day. He made only 12 but Australia broke the world record to take a 3–0 lead.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p247"/><ref>Fingleton, pp. 170–178.</ref>
The Australians moved onto the next match against [[Derbyshire County Cricket Club|Derbyshire]], where Miller scored a half-century and took 3/31 in an innings victory.<ref name="p247"/> Against [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]], Miller took two wickets before striking a hard-hitting 84 with five sixes. He struck one of the sixes with one hand, sending it 20 rows into the crowd.<ref name="p248"/><ref>Fingleton, p. 203.</ref> In a match against [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]],<ref name="p248">Perry, p. 248.</ref> [[Jack Ikin]] had reached 99 despite being repeatedly hit. Miller refused to bowl to Ikin, saying that he felt the batsman deserved a century. Lindwall was given the ball and promptly removed Ikin for 99.<ref name="p249"/>
The teams proceeded to [[The Oval]] for the Fifth Test. After England elected to bat,<ref name="p249">Perry, p. 249.</ref> Miller bowled [[John Dewes]] with his second ball and then removed [[Jack Crapp]] without scoring, leaving England at 4/23.<ref name="f184">Fingleton, p. 184.</ref> Miller ended with 2/5 as Lindwall (6/20) cut down the home team for 52. In his last Test innings for the summer, Miller scored five.<ref name="p250">Perry, p. 250.</ref> Australia led by 337 on the first innings and Miller dismissed Hutton and Crapp to end with 2/22 as Australia won by an innings and took a 4–0 series win.<ref name="p251">Perry, p. 251.</ref><ref>Fingleton, p. 187–189.</ref> Miller ended the Tests with 184 runs at 26.28 and 13 wickets at 23.15. He took eight catches.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p251"/>
In a match against the [[History of English amateur cricket#Amateurism in cricket|Gentlemen of England]] at [[Lord's]],<ref name="p251"/> Miller scored 69 and was dismissed attempting a third consecutive [[Batting (cricket)#Pull and hook|hooked]] boundary.<ref name="p252">Perry, p. 252.</ref> Australia went through the remaining tour matches unbeaten to end the summer without a defeat.<ref name=sched>{{cite web|title=Matches, Australia tour of England, Apr–September 1948 |url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/invincibles/engine/series/61329.html |publisher=ESPNcricinfo |accessdate=16 July 2008}}</ref>
After the tour, Bradman was full of praise for Miller, though somewhat critical of his aggressive batting: {{quote|One of the most volatile cricketers of any age. Long, rangy, athletic type—drove the ball with tremendous power—tried to hit sixes with abandon. Many of them would have been prodigious. Would have been a far better player had he curbed this propensity and showed more judgement in his hitting. Dangerous bowler with the new ball, swinging it both ways not much short of [Ray] Lindwall's speed. [...] In 1948 he was the best slip field in the world. Altogether, a crowd-pleasing personality ... whose limitations were caused mainly by his own failure to concentrate.|Don Bradman|<ref name="FarewellToCricket">Bradman, p. 225.</ref>}} <!--In his analysis of the tour, Bradman praised Miller for his new ball bowling, swinging the ball both ways at pace and judging him as the best slips catcher in the world.<ref name="p255"/> However, Bradman criticised Miller's hitting of sixes (26),<ref name="p255">Perry, p. 255.</ref> feeling the Miller had lacked restraint and concentration.<ref name="p256"/> --> Miller totalled 1,088 runs for the tour at an average of 47.30, only the eighth highest in the squad. He took 56 wickets at 17.58 and held onto 20 catches.<ref name="p256">Perry, p. 256.</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/records/averages/batting_bowling.html?class=4;id=1070;type=tour|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|title=Batting and bowling averages Australia tour of England, Apr–September 1948 – First-class matches|accessdate=10 December 2008}}</ref>
===Omission for South Africa=== [[File:DonaldBradman.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Don Bradman, Miller's former captain and cricket selector. Miller's conflicts with Bradman were believed to be the reason for his omission, and later, his non-appointment as Australian captain.]] After returning to Australia, Miller played against Bradman in a testimonial match in 1948–49. Miller bowled three consecutive bouncers at Bradman, dismissing him with the last of the short-pitched deliveries for 53.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/18/18791.html|title=AL Hassett's XI v AR Morris' XI, 25th, 26th, 28th February, 1st March 1949|accessdate=26 October 2011}}</ref><ref name="p261">Perry, p. 261.</ref><ref name=w163>Whitington, p. 163.</ref> Bradman was angered by Miller's bowling.<ref name="p261"/><ref name=w163/> One week later, the squad to tour [[South Africa]] in the following season was announced, and Miller was omitted,<ref name=h2/><ref name=w163/> despite being ranked as the best all rounder in the world.<ref name="p262">Perry, p. 262.</ref> During the Australian season, which was a purely domestic one, he had scored 400 runs at 33.33 and taken 11 wickets at 24.09.<ref name=h2/><ref name="p262"/> He scored one century against Queensland during the season, as well as a 99 against Victoria at the SCG.<ref name="p263">Perry, p. 263.</ref> The surprise omission led to much conjecturing about the reasoning.<ref name=w163/><ref name=po26>Pollard (1990), p. 26.</ref> One was that Miller had stated during the season that he did not want to bowl, so the selectors only considered his batting performances.<ref name="p263"/> Another was that Miller's bouncing of Bradman had provoked his former captain into voting against him at the selection table.<ref name=po26/> Rumours circulated that new captain [[Lindsay Hassett]] did not want Miller on the tour because he was undisciplined, which Hassett denied.<ref name=w164>Whitington, p. 164.</ref> Another was that [[Jack Ryder (cricketer)|Jack Ryder]], the Victorian selector and former Australian captain, had voted against Miller in retaliation for his move to New South Wales.<ref>Perry, pp. 263–264.</ref> Both Bradman and [[Chappie Dwyer]] claimed they voted for Miller, leading Miller to quip "somebody's telling lies", as there were only three on the selection panel.<ref name=po26/>
The media stridently criticised Miller's omission,<ref name=h3>Haigh (1997), p. 3.</ref> as did former players such as [[Stan McCabe]] and [[Alan Kippax]].<ref name=w166>Whitington, p. 166.</ref> During the off season, he worked as a journalist and played [[baseball]],<ref name="p264">Perry, p. 264.</ref> but declined a trial with a [[Major League Baseball]] club, the [[Boston Red Sox]].<ref name="p265">Perry, p. 265.</ref> Miller captained New South Wales at the start of the 1949–50 season as his colleagues went to South Africa, his first leadership experience in the Sheffield Shield.<ref name="p265"/> He scored 80 and took six wickets in the first match against Queensland. After another victory over Western Australia,<ref name=w198>Whitington, p. 198.</ref> he received a request from the Australian Board of Control. At the request of captain Hassett, Miller was asked to tour South Africa as cover for Johnston, who had been injured in a car crash.<ref name=po26/><ref name="p266">Perry, p. 266.</ref><ref name=h9>Haigh (1997), p. 9.</ref><ref name=w165>Whitington, p. 165.</ref> Miller accepted the offer and resigned himself to bowling heavily.<ref name="p267">Perry, p. 267.</ref><ref name=w167>Whitington, p. 167.</ref> Miller almost missed the trip after arriving late at the dock in [[Perth, Western Australia|Perth]] after a drunken night. The next boat to South Africa would not have departed for several weeks.<ref>Perry, pp. 267–268.</ref> Despite his recall, there remained tension over his initial omission, as Dwyer was the team manager.<ref name=h10>Haigh (1997), p. 10.</ref>
Miller was given the responsibility of batting in the [[batting order (cricket)|number three]] position when Hassett was afflicted by [[tonsillitis]].<ref name="p270">Perry, p. 270.</ref> In the First Test at [[Johannesburg]], Miller scored 21 and then took 5/40 in South Africa's first innings,<ref name=w172>Whitington, p. 172.</ref> only his second match on tour,<ref name=po28>Pollard (1990), p. 28.</ref> resulting in the home side being forced to follow on and lose by an innings.<ref name="testlist"/> In the Second Test at [[Cape Town]], he scored 58 and then took 3/54 in the first innings.<ref name=po28/><ref name="p271">Perry, p. 271.</ref> On the third morning, Miller crashed his car and arrived late to the ground, still putting on his trousers as he entered the playing field. Despite, this he dismissed [[Dudley Nourse]] with his third ball.<ref name="p272">Perry, p. 272.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 172–175.</ref> He was wicketless in the second innings, and took only one in the Third Test in [[Durban]] and did not pass 10 with the bat.<ref name="testlist"/> Australia won both matches.<ref name="p278">Perry, p. 278.</ref> He returned to the form in the Fourth Test with 84, 33 not out and 3/75 in a high scoring draw.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p279">Perry, p. 279.</ref><ref name=po29>Pollard (1990), p. 29.</ref> Miller took match figures of 5/66 in the Fifth Test as Australia took the series 4–0. He ended the series with 246 runs at 41.00 and 17 wickets at 22.94,<ref name="testlist"/><ref>Whitington, pp. 188–190.</ref> placing in the top six in the Test averages for bat and ball.<ref name="p281">Perry, p. 281.</ref> During the tour matches, he took match figures of 11/54 against Natal Country Districts and scored a century against [[Transvaal cricket team|Transvaal]].<ref>Perry, pp. 273, 280.</ref>
===Ashes in Australia=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:AusCricketTeam1950.jpg|thumb|left|The Australian Test cricket team for the First Test against England in the [[1950–51 Ashes series]]. Miller is front row, far right.]] --> Miller started the 1950–51 season with an unbeaten 201 in a Shield match against Queensland. At 438 minutes, it was his longest first-class innings.<ref name="p285">Perry, p. 285.</ref><ref name=w199>Whitington, p. 199.</ref> In the return match, he scored 138 not out in just 118 minutes in a successful run-chase, a sharp contrast to his double-century.<ref name="p286">Perry, p. 286.</ref><ref name=w200>Whitington, p. 200.</ref> In a tour match against the visiting England team at the SCG before the Test series, Miller scored 214, having been 99 not out at stumps on the previous day.<ref name="p287">Perry, p. 287.</ref><ref name=w201>Whitington, p. 201.</ref> He hit 15 fours and three sixes.<ref name=po38>Pollard (1990), p. 38.</ref> However, he made ducks in consecutive matches leading into the First Test in Brisbane.<ref>Perry, pp. 288–290.</ref> Miller scored 15 and eight on a rain-affected pitch,<ref name=po39>Pollard (1990), p. 39.</ref> and took match figures of 3/50 in an Australian victory, dismissing Dewes twice.<ref name="testlist"/><ref>Perry, pp. 290–291.</ref><ref name=w202>Whitington, p. 202.</ref> He had another quiet match in the Second Test, scoring 18 and 14 and taking a match total of 2/55.<ref name="testlist"/><ref>Perry, pp. 293–294.</ref> After struggling in the first two Tests, Miller rediscovered his batting form with 98 against the tourists for New South Wales.<ref name="p294">Perry, p. 294.</ref><ref name=po41>Pollard (1990), p. 41.</ref><ref name=w203>Whitington, p. 203.</ref>
England had started the Third Test at Sydney strongly. Australia took its first wicket when Miller caught Washbrook from Johnson with a horizontal diving catch at slip.<ref name=w2045/> England were still in control at 1/128 when Miller came on to bowl.<ref name="p295">Perry, p. 295.</ref> He removed Hutton and [[Reg Simpson]] before bowling Compton for a duck.<ref name=po41/><ref name=w2045/> In the space of four overs from Miller, England were now 4/137. Miller had contributed to all four wickets.<ref name="p296"/> Miller ended with 4/37 as England were bowled out for 290 on the second day.<ref name=po41/> Miller batted patiently on the third day, reaching 96 by stumps with Australia at 6/362. The next day, with his century four runs away, Miller arrived late, leaving his batting partner Johnson waiting at the players' gate.<ref name="p296">Perry, p. 296.</ref> Miller progressed to 145 not out despite the interruption. It has been a patient innings by his standards, taking almost a day.<ref name=w2045>Whitington, pp. 204–205.</ref><ref name="p296"/> England collapsed for 123, leaving Australia to take an innings victory.<ref name=po41/><ref>Perry, pp. 296–297.</ref> In the first innings of the Fourth Test in Sydney, Miller scored 44 and did not take a wicket, but he was heading for consecutive Test centuries in the second innings. He reached 99 when a [[leg break]] from [[Doug Wright (cricketer)|Doug Wright]] spun across him and clipped the off [[bail (cricket)|bail]].<ref name="p299">Perry, p. 299.</ref> The innings helped Australia to set England a target of 503. Miller took 3/27 on the final day, helping to cut through the middle order as Australia won by 274 runs.<ref name="p300">Perry, p. 300.</ref><ref name=po43>Pollard (1990), p. 43.</ref><ref name=w206>Whitington, p. 206.</ref> Miller was out for seven and a duck in the Fifth Test at the MCG. He took 4/76 in the first innings, joining Lindwall in cutting down the middle order, despite which England won by eight wickets.<ref name=po44>Pollard (1990), p. 44.</ref> Miller topped the Test batting averages with 350 runs at 43.75,<ref name=po45>Pollard (1990), p. 45.</ref> and for the entire first-class season, he scored 1332 runs at 78.35, the highest among all comers.<ref name="p300"/> His bowling was also strong, with 17 wickets at 17.70, second only to [[Jack Iverson]] (21 wickets at 15.23). However, an attack by Morris (182) and Miller (83) in a Shield match dispirited Iverson, and he never played Test cricket again.<ref name="p301">Perry, p. 301.</ref><ref name=po46>Pollard (1990), p. 46.</ref>
===West Indies tour Australia=== The 1951–52 Australian season saw the first tour by a [[West Indies cricket team|West Indian team]] in two decades. The Caribbean team had beaten England 3–1 in 1950 and were regarded as the biggest threat to Australia since ''[[Bodyline]]''.<ref name="p303">Perry, p. 303.</ref> The batting was led by the "three Ws": [[Everton Weekes]], [[Frank Worrell]] and [[Clyde Walcott]].
