The English had also been bamboozled by the [[leg spin]] and [[left arm orthodox]] of [[Sonny Ramadhin]] and [[Alf Valentine]], who took 59 wickets between them in four Tests against England.<ref name="p303"/><ref>Pollard (1990), pp. 49–50.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 207–208.</ref> Miller and Lindwall were charged with attacking the opposition batsmen, testing them with short-pitched bowling.<ref>Perry, pp. 304–306.</ref><ref name=po51>Pollard (1990), p. 51.</ref> The West Indies batted first in the First Test at Brisbane and were dismissed for 216; Miller dismissing their captain [[John Goddard (cricketer)|John Goddard]].<ref name="p306">Perry, p. 306.</ref><ref name=w209>Whitington, p. 209.</ref> Miller came to the crease at 3/80 and could not pick Ramadhin. He decided to attack the leg spinner without picking him. He missed some, was dropped twice and hit a six before falling for 46 to Valentine. Australia scraped out a 10-run lead.<ref name=po51/><ref name=w209/><ref>Perry, pp. 306–307.</ref> Miller took another wicket in the second innings but managed only four as Australia stumbled to a three-wicket victory.<ref name="p307"/> Between Tests, Miller took eight wickets in the match as New South Wales beat the tourists in a tour match.<ref name=po52>Pollard (1990), p. 52.</ref> In the Second Test at Sydney, Miller came to the crease at 3/106 having gone wicketless in the West Indies' first innings of 362.<ref name="p307">Perry, p. 307.</ref> He began to pick Ramadhin and finished with 129 in 246 minutes. Miller and Hassett put on 235, an Australian Test record for any wicket against the West Indies.<ref name=w209/><ref name=po52/> Ramadhin ended with 1/196 and was demoralised.<ref name=w210>Whitington, p. 210.</ref> In the second innings, Miller took 3/50 with a heavy barrage of short balls and claimed two catches to help Australia to a seven-wicket victory.<ref name=po52/><ref>Perry, pp. 308–309.</ref> ''Wisden'' decried Lindwall and Miller's "relentless bumper tactics".<ref name="p309"/>
Miller had a lean Third Test, taking only one wicket and scoring four and 35,<ref name="testlist"/> as Australia lost by six wickets.<ref name="p309">Perry, p. 309.</ref> In the Fourth Test at the MCG, the West Indies batted first and Miller removed both openers in the first hour, before returning to end with 5/60 as the tourists were bowled out for 272. He then scored 47 as Australia managed only 216. He took 2/49, but only scored two in Australia's run-chase of 259. The home team won by one wicket.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p310">Perry, p. 310.</ref> In the Fifth Test, Miller took 5/26 in the first innings with another concentrated display of short-pitched bowling,<ref name=po53>Pollard (1990), p. 53.</ref> and then scored 69 in the second innings. He took two further wickets in the second innings as Australia fell short of their target.<ref name="testlist"/> Miller ended the series as the leading bowler, with 20 wickets at 19.90. He was second in the batting, with 362 runs at 40.22.<ref name="p311">Perry, p. 311.</ref> Throughout the series, Miller and Lindwall were repeatedly successful with their concerted bouncer tactics, which were heavily criticised.<ref name=po54>Pollard (1990), p. 54.</ref>
After the Test series ended, Miller captained a [[Commonwealth XI cricket team|Commonwealth XI]] that played against a touring England team in [[Colombo]], [[Sri Lanka|Ceylon]]. England had been on a tour of the [[Indian subcontinent]]. Miller scored 106 as the Commonwealth compiled 517. Miller took three wickets in the first innings and led his team to a victory by an innings and 259 runs.<ref>Perry, pp. 312–313.</ref>
===Captain of New South Wales=== [[File:Miller Morris.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Miller and Morris walk out to bat for New South Wales]] [[File:Sid Barnes, Adelaide Oval 1952.jpg|thumb|upright|Sid Barnes, dressed in suit and tie and carrying a range of toiletry items. This incident was said to be held against Miller when the Australian Board of Control considered Hassett's replacement as Australian captain.]] At the start of the 1952–53 season, the [[New South Wales Cricket Association]]'s five-man selection panel installed Miller as captain in place of Morris. This was despite Morris leading the state to the Sheffield Shield in the previous season.<ref name=po54/> Miller did not lobby for the job, but the Sydney media had campaigned for Miller, suggesting that his flamboyant style would attract more spectators and help stem the financial losses of the NSWCA. Despite this, Morris remained the Test vice-captain ahead of Miller.<ref>Perry, pp. 314–315.</ref><ref name=po57>Pollard (1990), p. 57.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 211–214.</ref>
In his first match as leader, Miller scored 109 against Queensland. Taking 260 minutes, it was the slowest century of his career.<ref name=p3156/><ref name=w215>Whitington, p. 215.</ref> In another match against the touring South Africans, Miller elected to field and reduced his opponents to 3/3 and went on to win by five wickets.<ref name=p3156>Perry, pp. 315–316.</ref> His players respected him, and some began to mimic his cough, voice, gait and idiosyncrasies. [[Richie Benaud]] unbuttoned his shirt in Miller's mould.<ref name="p316">Perry, p. 316.</ref><ref name=w214>Whitington, p. 214.</ref> He captained in an unorthodox manner, often trying unusual ploys to unsettle the opposition. He encouraged the opposition to attack in an attempt to get a wicket, and often shuffled his batting order to suit the circumstances of his batsmen.<ref name="w215" /><ref name="p317">Perry, p. 317.</ref> He was soon called before authorities after a match against South Australia. Sid Barnes, his [[List of cricket terms#T|12th man]], had come onto the ground with drinks, dressed as a flight attendant. He also brought things such as cigars, mirrors and combs. Barnes' antics extended the break longer than usual. Miller was called before the NSWCA after the [[South Australian Cricket Association]] lodged a complaint, and had to give an assurance that such an incident would not be repeated.<ref>Perry, pp. 318–319.</ref><ref>Pollard (1990), pp. 57–58.</ref>
Miller started the Test series against South Africa poorly. Suffering from a throat infection,<ref name="p320"/> he scored three in both innings and took 1/46 in an Australian victory.<ref name="p319">Perry, p. 319.</ref> In the Second Test at the MCG, Miller performed consistently with bat and ball, taking 4/62 and 3/51 and scoring 52 and 31. In the course of the match, he passed the all-round double of 1000 Test runs and 100 Test wickets when he dismissed [[John Waite (cricketer)|John Waite]] in the second innings, but this was not enough to prevent defeat.<ref name="p319"/><ref name=w216>Whitington, p. 216.</ref> In the Third Test, Miller scored 55, putting on 168 with Harvey,<ref name=po61>Pollard (1990), p. 61.</ref> and took 3/48 and 2/33 in an innings victory.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p320"/> Australia's fortunes took a turn for the worse in the Fourth Test in Adelaide. Miller scored nine and injured his back after two overs with the ball. Lindwall also broke down.<ref name="p320">Perry, p. 320.</ref> Without their spearheads, Australia were unable to bowl out the South Africans and match was drawn.<ref name=po61/><ref name=w217>Whitington, p. 217.</ref> Both were ruled out of the Fifth Test and the South Africans levelled the series despite conceding 520 runs during the first innings. Australia's bowlers were unable to stop the South African batsmen without their new ball pair.<ref name=po61/><ref name=w217/><ref>{{cite web|title= 5th Test: Australia v South Africa at Melbourne February 6–12, 1953|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/ci/engine/match/62750.html| publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 July 2008}}</ref>
===1953 Ashes tour=== {{main|Keith Miller with the Australian cricket team in England in 1953}}
Australia proceeded to the [[Australian cricket team in England in 1953|1953 Ashes tour]].<ref name="p322">Perry, p. 322.</ref> During a stopover at [[Naples]], Miller was locked inside after entering a private opera rehearsal without authorisation, but managed to escape and rejoin the boat as it was about to leave.<ref name="p322"/> During his career, several cricket books were published under Miller's name, and he was embroiled in further controversy when one ghost-written tome, which was printed as the team left for England, criticised his captain Hassett as being too cautious.<ref name="p323">Perry, p. 323.</ref><ref name="p324">Perry, p. 324.</ref><ref name=w219221>Whitington, pp. 219–221.</ref>
The burden on Miller and Lindwall increased when Johnston broke down in an early tour game.<ref name="p256" /> Miller was wicketless against Worcestershire, but succeeded with the bat, scoring an unbeaten 220 in just over six hours.<ref name="p327">Perry, p. 327.</ref><ref name=w221>Whitington, p. 221.</ref> He then scored 159 not out against Yorkshire.<ref name="p327"/><ref name=w222>Whitington, p. 222.</ref> At this point, Miller had scored 421 runs in the week of May, and the media began to speculate that he could score 1000 runs in one month, something that had been done on a tour only by Bradman.<ref name=w222/><ref name="p328">Perry, p. 328.</ref>
Miller's love of [[Thoroughbred horse race|horseracing]] then interfered with his quest. Wanting to attend an afternoon race meeting, he opened the batting in the morning against [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]]. Not intending to play a long innings, he attacked the bowling and was out for 20, before heading for the track.<ref>Perry, pp. 328–329.</ref><ref name=w220>Whitington, p. 220.</ref> He stayed at the track until late afternoon, and returned to find the Australians walking out to field.<ref name="a119"/> This was followed by a match against the MCC at Lord's where he took four wickets of English Test players.<ref name=w222/><ref name="p329">Perry, p. 329.</ref> Miller then took match figures of 5/27 against [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford University]].<ref name="p329"/><ref name="p330">Perry, p. 330.</ref><ref name=w223>Whitington, p. 223.</ref> In the match against Essex, Miller pulled rib muscles, meaning he could not bowl in the First Test at Trent Bridge. He scored 55 and five in a rain-affected draw.<ref name="Perry, pp. 331–332">Perry, pp. 331–332.</ref>
Australia travelled to [[Bramall Lane]] under the captaincy of Miller. Captain Hassett and his deputy Morris were rested and stayed in London with the team manager. After the first day's play, he organised a party for that lasted until the next afternoon—the rest day. He woke up with a hangover the next day just minutes before the start of play. Improvising, Miller arrived at the ground in a [[hearse]].<ref name="p332">Perry, p. 332.</ref> When it was Australia's turn to bat, Miller was the last man to be dismissed, having scored 86 despite his hangover.<ref name="p333">Perry, p. 333.</ref>
The Test series moved to Lord's. Miller resumed bowling, sending down 42 overs and taking a total of 1/74. He managed 25 in the first innings, but promoted to number three in the second innings, he batted patiently to reach stumps before reaching his first Test century on English soil the following morning,<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p334">Perry, p. 334.</ref> but England held on for a draw.<ref name="p335">Perry, p. 335.</ref> More than half of the Third Test at Old Trafford was washed out, resulting in another draw. Miller took 1/38 bowling fast off breaks and scored 17 and six.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p335" /> Australia then played Middlesex at Lord's, where Miller scored a hard-hitting 71.<ref>Perry, pp. 335–336.</ref>
Australia elected to field on a wet wicket in the Fourth Test at Headingley. Miller dismissed Edrich and Graveney and ended with 2/39 from 38 overs as England were bowled out for 167.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="leeds56">Perry, pp. 336–337</ref> Miller made only five in the first innings. In the second innings, Miller and Lindwall launched a short-pitched barrage and dismissed Watson and Simpson in consecutive balls. England were 5/177 a stumps on day four, leading by 78.<ref name="p337">Perry, p. 337.</ref><ref name=w224>Whitington, p. 224.</ref> The pacemen were booed from the field.<ref name="p338"/><ref name=w225>Whitington, p. 225.</ref> The next day, Miller dismissed Evans early, before [[Trevor Bailey]] began his resistance.<ref name="Perry, pp. 331–332"/><ref name="p338"/> Frustrated by Bailey's defensive style and time-wasting, Miller lost his cool and aimed a [[Beamer (cricket)|beamer]] straight at Bailey's head, further angering the crowd.<ref name="p338">Perry, p. 338.</ref> Miller ended with 4/63 from a long spell of 47 overs.<ref name="p339">Perry, p. 339.</ref> England held on for another draw after more time-wasting by Bailey. The teams headed for the Fifth Test at The Oval tied 0–0.<ref name="p340">Perry, p. 340.</ref> Miller's last Test performance was his least productive; he scored one and a duck and took a total of 2/89. England won the match and regained the Ashes.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p341">Perry, p. 341.</ref> Miller's returns were below his career standards, with 223 runs at 24.77 and 10 wickets at 30.30. He took two catches.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p342">Perry, p. 342.</ref>
Miller scored 67 against the Gentlemen of England at Lord's and then played against the Combined Services at [[Sabina Park|Kingston]]. He reached his century before lunch and then proceeded to 262 not out with 24 boundaries. This included a 377-run fourth-wicket stand by [[Jim de Courcy]] in only 205 minutes, in particular targeting [[Fred Trueman]]'s bowling.<ref name="p343">Perry, p. 343.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 228–229.</ref> He then took 3/17 with the ball.<ref name="p344">Perry, p. 344.</ref> He finished the English summer with 1,433 runs at 51.17, the second highest average behind Harvey among batsmen with over 200 runs.<ref name="p344"/> He was the only Australian to hit two double centuries and also took 45 wickets at 22.51.<ref name="p344"/> For his efforts that summer, ''Wisden Cricketers' Almanack'' named him one of its [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Five Cricketers of the Year]].<ref name="WCOTY">{{cite web|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/154607.html|title=Cricketer of the year – 1954: Keith Miller|work=Wisden Cricketers' Almanack |publisher=[[Wisden]] |year=1954|accessdate=1 July 2008}}</ref>
===Overlooked for Test captaincy=== {{see also|Ian Johnson (cricketer)}} [[File:Ian Johnson.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Ian Johnson, Miller's rival for the position of Test captain]] Miller returned to Australia and led New South Wales to the Sheffield Shield title in 1953–54.<ref name=po79>Pollard (1990), p. 79.</ref><ref name=w235>Whitington, p. 235.</ref> He topped the Australian first-class batting averages with 71.10, but had his poorest season with the ball, taking only 16 wickets at 38.75.<ref>Perry, pp. 348–349.</ref> The season was purely domestic with no touring side and therefore no Test matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aus.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/1950S/1953-54/| title=Match/series archive| publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=4 December 2007}}</ref> The season was also a transition point in Australian cricket, as Hassett retired upon return to Australia.<ref name="p346"/> Initially, Morris and Miller were the two frontrunners for the captaincy. Miller was the state captain, but Morris was the vice-captain of the Test team ahead of Miller.<ref>Perry, pp. 347–348.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 232–233.</ref> At the time, Johnson had been dropped from the Australian team, but inherited the Victorian captaincy from Hassett, who accused him of not trying. Hassett told Johnson that he could become Test captain if he regained his form and his Test position.<ref name="p346"/><ref name=po80>Pollard (1990), p. 80.</ref> As the outgoing captain, Hassett was believed to have an influence over the selection of his successor. Miller had also criticised Hassett in his book,<ref name="p346">Perry, p. 346.</ref> and there was talk that Hassett was upset about Miller's departure from South Melbourne and Victoria.<ref name="a119"/> Johnson returned to form with 45 wickets at 22.75 for the season.<ref name="p349">Perry, p. 349.</ref><ref name=po81>Pollard (1990), p. 81.</ref>
[[English cricket team in Australia in 1954–55|England toured Australia in the 1954–55 season]].<ref name=po82>Pollard (1990), p. 82.</ref> Johnson was selected to lead an Australian XI in a tour match against the Englishmen before the Tests, an indication of the selectors' inclination. He took 6/66 in England's only innings.<ref name=p352/><ref name=po83>Pollard (1990), p. 83.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 233–234.</ref> The build-up featured a media war, with Melbourne newspapers stumping for Johnson while the Sydney journalists trumpeted Miller.<ref>Whitington, pp. 234–235.</ref> Miller warmed up for the Tests with 86 for New South Wales against England. On 18 November, the Australian Board of Control selected Johnson as captain, with Morris as his deputy.<ref name="p352"/><ref name=po83/> Miller's irreverent nature was cited as a possible reason for the board's selection. Johnson was regarded as a superior diplomat,<ref>Mallett, pp. 69–70.</ref><ref name=po76>Pollard (1990), p. 76.</ref> while Miller had a reputation for turning up late and being undisciplined.<ref>Perry, pp. 346–347.</ref> Miller had frequently been in dispute with Bradman, who was a member of the board and the chairman of selectors.<ref name="a119"/><ref>Whitington, pp. 239–242.</ref> Miller had also questioned where revenue that the board collected from ticket sales was being used.<ref name="a119"/> Others claimed that Johnson was appointed because he was part of the establishment; his father [[William Johnson (cricketer, born 1884)|Bill]] was a former Australian selector.<ref name=po84>Pollard (1990), p. 84.</ref> The decision was bitterly criticised by the Sydney press.{{quote|There is strong feeling amongst cricket enthusiasts that horse trading on a state basis rather than objective evaluation of cricket skills has dominated selectors discussions. The operating principle seems to have been "you look after my man and we'll look after yours."|[[The Daily Telegraph (Australia)|The Daily Telegraph]] editorial|<ref name="Haigh">Haigh (2006), p. 85.</ref>}}
[[File:Miller bowl front.jpg|thumb|upright|Miller bowling in the Third Test]] Miller scored 49 in the First Test at Brisbane as Australia amassed 8/601, before dismissing Simpson and Hutton as England fell to an innings defeat.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p352">Perry, p. 352.</ref><ref name=po84/><ref>Whitington, pp. 245–246.</ref> A knee injury forced Miller to miss the Second Test at the SCG, which England won.<ref name=po84/><ref name="p353">Perry, p. 353.</ref><ref name=w248>Whitington, p. 248.</ref> Miller returned for the Third Test at the MCG, but was initially unavailable to bowl due to lingering knee problems.<ref name="p354">Perry, p. 354.</ref> However, upon receiving an inquiry about the health of his knee before the match by [[Prime Minister of Australia]] [[Robert Menzies]], Miller agreed to try to bowl for a short period and lift his team.<ref name="p355">Perry, p. 355.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 249–250.</ref> England elected to bat and Miller removed Hutton, Edrich and Compton with his outswinger. He ended up bowling for the entire first session of play and had 3/5 at lunch from nine overs, before finishing at 3/14. England were bowled out for 191.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p355"/><ref name=po85>Pollard (1990), p. 85.</ref> Miller struggled with the bat, scoring six and seven as [[Frank Tyson]]'s pace saw England inflict a second successive defeat on Australia.<ref>Perry, pp. 356–357.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 250–252.</ref> Australia needed to win the Fourth Test in Adelaide to keep the series alive. Miller scored 44 and 14 as Australia were bowled out in the second innings to leave England with 94 for victory. Miller made a late burst, removing Edrich, Hutton and [[Colin Cowdrey]] in consecutive overs to leave England at 3/18.<ref name="p358">Perry, p. 358.</ref> He then took a difficult catch from Johnston to dismiss [[Peter May (cricketer)|Peter May]].<ref name=m67>Mallett, p. 67.</ref> England were then 4/49 but hung on to win by five wickets and secure the Ashes.<ref name="p359">Perry, p. 359.</ref><ref name=po87>Pollard (1990), p. 87.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 253–254.</ref> It was the first time that Australia had lost three consecutive Tests since the ''Bodyline'' series of 1932–33.<ref name="auslist"/> Miller made 19 and 28 in the rain-affected draw in the Fifth Test. He ended the series with 167 runs at 23.86, his lowest ever at international level,<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p360">Perry, p. 360.</ref> and took 10 wickets at 24.30.<ref name="p361">Perry, p. 361.</ref>
He had more success as domestic level. New South Wales beat Victoria in two days at the SCG to win the Sheffield Shield; Miller taking five wickets in the second innings.<ref name="p357">Perry, p. 357.</ref> He also led his state in a 45-run win over the tourists, their only defeat apart from the First Test.<ref name=po87/> The match was marked by a quickfire 71 in 57 minutes and his team's attacking strategy.<ref>Perry, pp. 359–360.</ref><ref name="w254"/>
===West Indies tour===
After leading his state to another Sheffield Shield title and a win over England,<ref name=w254>Whitington, p. 254.</ref> Miller replaced Morris as the vice-captain for the tour of the [[West Indies]] that started in early 1955.<ref name="p357"/><ref name=po89>Pollard (1990), p. 89.</ref> Australia was looking for its first series win against any team in three years, having lost two consecutive series to England.<ref name=auslist/><ref name="p363">Perry, p. 363.</ref> Australia batted first in the opening Test at [[Sabina Park]] in [[Jamaica]].<ref name="p364">Perry, p. 364.</ref> Miller came to the wicket at 2/137 and put on a 224-run partnership with Harvey. Both ended with centuries and Miller scored his highest Test score of 147, striking 15 fours.<ref name=po93>Pollard (1990), p. 93.</ref><ref name=w2623>Whitington, pp. 262–263.</ref> When Valentine and Ramadhin had conceded 100 runs, he respectively shook their hands.<ref name=w2623/><ref name="p365">Perry, p. 365.</ref> Australia finished at 9/515. Johnson had been injured when hit in the foot by a [[yorker]] so Miller was left in charge of the team on the field with Australia one bowler short.<ref name=w2623/><ref name="p365"/> Miller attempted to unsettle the batsmen by placing many men close to the bat in an attempt to insult their batting capabilities. He took the new ball at 5/239 and the hosts collapsed to be all out for 259.<ref name="p366"/> Miller had taken 2/36,<ref name="testlist"/> and enforced the [[follow-on]], which was questioned as paceman [[Ron Archer]] had broken down. With Australia two bowlers short, the West Indies moved to 1/114. When Weekes arrived at the crease, Miller unsettled him with delaying tactics, and he was out for one.<ref name="p366">Perry, p. 366.</ref> He then placed two [[Fielding (cricket)#Fielding position names and locations|silly points]] and two silly mid-ons in an attempt to unsettle Walcott, who fell to Lindwall soon after. Miller then took two wickets and the hosts had lost three wickets in as many overs. The West Indies were bowled out and Australia won by nine wickets.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name=w2645>Whitington, pp. 264–265.</ref> Miller had taken 3/62 in the second innings.<ref name="testlist"/>
Johnson resumed the leadership on the field in the Second Test at [[Queen's Park Oval]] in [[Trinidad]]. The match was a high-scoring draw, but Miller scored only three and took match figures of 1/148.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name=po93/><ref>Perry, pp. 368–369.</ref> In the Third Test at [[Georgetown, Guyana]], Miller removed both openers in the first innings and then scored 33 as Australia by eight wickets. He took 3/51 for the match.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p370">Perry, p. 370.</ref> In the Fourth Test at [[Bridgetown, Barbados]], Miller came to the wicket with Australia at 3/226 on the first day. The tourists lost two more wickets to be 5/233. Miller and Archer launched a counter-attacking partnership of 206. Miller reached 137 and then walked after edging a ball, even though none of the opposition had appealed.<ref name="p371">Perry, p. 371.</ref> Australia reached 668 and the West Indies were struggling at 6/147, with Miller having dismissed Weekes and [[Collie Smith]] in the same over.<ref name="cap196">Perry, pp. 196–197.</ref> At the time, Miller was bowling at medium pace, but Johnson felt that the new batsmen [[Denis Atkinson]] and [[Clairmonte Depeiaza]] were vulnerable to express pace. Johnson ordered Miller to bowl fast, but was turned down. Johnson replaced Miller with Lindwall, who was tired and was hit around the ground.<ref name="cap196"/><ref name=po94>Pollard (1990), p. 94.</ref> The pair seized the initiative and compiled a world Test record of 347 for the seventh wicket and the Australians were tired after failing to break the partnership.<ref name=po94/><ref>Perry, pp. 371–372.</ref><ref name=w276>Whitington, p. 276.</ref> Miller attacked Johnson in front of the other players, saying "You couldn't captain a bunch of bloody schoolboys!"<ref name="p372"/> Johnson then offered to resolve the dispute "out the back",<ref name="p372"/> implying a fisticuffs.<ref name=po94/><ref name=w276/><ref name="p372">Perry, p. 372.</ref>
Miller declined the offer and stopped.<ref name=po94/><ref name="p372"/> The match resumed the next day and the West Indies were eventually bowled out 158 behind. Miller had been punished by the batsmen, taking 2/113 from 22 overs.<ref name="testlist"/> Miller scored 10 and took 1/66 in the second innings as the match ended in a high-scoring draw.<ref name="p373">Perry, p. 373.</ref> Miller then took 6/107 in the first innings of the Fifth Test in Jamaica. He removed [[John Holt (cricketer)|John Holt]], Walcott and Smith, before taking three tail-end wickets as the home team were bowled out for 357. When Australia batted, Miller arrived at the crease to join Harvey with the score at 3/302. He added his third century of the series and ended with 109 as Australia reached 8/758. He took 2/58 in the second innings as Australia completed a 3–0 win.<ref>Perry, pp. 373–374.</ref><ref name=po95>Pollard (1990), p. 95.</ref> It was Miller's most statistically successful series, with 439 runs at 73.17 and the 20 wickets at 32.05 made him the equal leading wicket-taker along with Lindwall.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p374">Perry, p. 374.</ref><ref name=w277>Whitington, p. 277.</ref>
===Final domestic season=== Miller started the 1955–56 season, which was purely domestic,<ref name=auslist/> with 164 against Queensland in Brisbane. On the final day, Miller set the hosts 275 for victory in three hours. He lengthened the innings break by seven minutes, by remonstrating with officials to pause the match for the running of the [[Melbourne Cup]]. They agreed and the match was stopped for 13 minutes for the race.<ref name="p376">Perry, p. 376.</ref> Queensland lost seven wickets but held on for a draw, aided by the 20 minutes lost by Miller's love of horseracing.<ref name="p377">Perry, p. 377.</ref>
The next match was against South Australia in Sydney. New South Wales had declared at 8/215 and the visitors were 0/2 at stumps on the first day. Miller's wife gave birth to their fourth child, and Miller was drinking into the next morning. He then arrived at the SCG, having forgotten to pick up team-mate [[Peter Philpott]] as arranged, so he had to rush back and the pair arrived late for the day's play.<ref name="a119"/><ref name="p377"/> Miller was still in a tuxedo as play was about to start.<ref name="m65"/> Miller completed the unfinished over from the previous night and felt that the pitch did not offer any assistance. He then told [[Alan Davidson (cricketer, born 1929)|Alan Davidson]] to bowl the next over from his end. However, as Davidson was about to bowl, Miller changed his mind and took over.<ref name="p377"/> Miller bowled [[Les Favell]] in the over. He kept on bowling and finished with 7/12 from 7.3 overs, clean bowling five of his victims. The visitors had been levelled for 27,<ref name="a119">Armstrong, p. 119.</ref> the lowest score in the history of the Sheffield Shield.<ref name=p97/><ref name="p378"/> Miller then asked South Australia to follow-on,<ref name=m66>Mallett, p. 66.</ref> but showed little interest in bowling again, delivering only six overs despite the bowler-friendly conditions. Philpott said that "this was typical Miller. He was never an accumulator of records, not particularly concerned with figures."<ref name="p378">Perry, p. 378.</ref> In another incident, Miller had been making a speech at a civic reception for the New South Wales team in the town of [[Maitland, New South Wales|Maitland]]. In front of the mayor at the town hall, he praised the hospitality,<ref name="p380"/> before turning around to his players and asking what the name of the town was.<ref name="p380">Perry, p. 380.</ref><ref name=m70>Mallett, p. 70.</ref><ref name=po78>Pollard (1990), p. 78.</ref> Miller then turned up late to a coaching clinic the next day and instead of teaching, he made a speech, advising the children to play tennis as there was more money on offer.<ref name=m70/>
In January 1956, Miller injured his back in a match against Queensland.<ref name=po97/> He suffered spasms that forced him to miss the rest of the season. He had scored 403 runs at 80.60 and taken 19 wickets at 14.94.<ref>Perry, pp. 382–383.</ref> New South Wales again won the Sheffield Shield.<ref name=po97>Pollard (1990), p. 97.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/australia/content/story/260057.html|accessdate=30 November 2007|title=A history of the Sheffield Shield|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|first=Martin|last=Williamson}}</ref>
===Final Ashes tour=== {{main|Keith Miller with the Australian cricket team in England in 1956}} [[File:Keith Miller.JPG|thumb|upright|Miller preparing to play a drive]] Miller was selected for the [[Australian cricket team in England in 1956|1956 Ashes tour]],<ref name="p384">Perry, p. 384.</ref><ref name="p385">Perry, p. 385.</ref> but could not bowl for a month because of a back injury from the first match.<ref name="p386">Perry, p. 386.</ref> Miller captained the Australians against Leicester. Coming in at 3/175, Miller made his highest first-class score of 281 not out, striking 35 fours in six and a half hours.<ref name="p386"/> A tougher fight awaited against Surrey at The Oval, who had England's Test spin combination of Laker and [[Tony Lock]]. Miller came in at 3/124 and struggled, scoring 18 runs in his first 120 minutes, his slowest two hours of scoring in his career.<ref name="p387">Perry, p. 387.</ref> As his partners continued to fall Miller ended unbeaten on 57 as Australia were bowled out for 259; Laker taking all ten wickets. Australia lost by ten wickets, its first loss to a county since 1912.<ref name="p387"/> As a result, sections of the Australian media began campaigning for Miller to replace Johnson as captain.<ref name="p388">Perry, p. 388.</ref><ref name=w284>Whitington, p. 284.</ref>
By the First Test at Trent Bridge, Miller was shouldering most of the bowling load. He sent down 52 overs in a rain-affected match, taking match figures of 6/127. He struggled with the bat, making a duck and four.<ref name="p389">Perry, p. 389.</ref> The teams headed to Lord's where Miller had to carry the pace attack without the injured Davidson and Lindwall. Crawford and [[Ken Mackay]] were called in to make their debut and support Miller with the pace duties.<ref name="p393">Perry, p. 393.</ref> Australia batted first and Miller managed 28. Australia managed only 285 and Crawford injured himself, exacerbating the burden on Miller. Miller had [[Peter Richardson (cricketer)|Peter Richardson]] and then bowled [[Tom Graveney]] with an outswinger. England were 2/32 and their captain [[Peter May (cricketer)|Peter May]] received an [[inswinger]] from Miller first ball, which he inside edged onto his stumps, but the bail was not dislodged.<ref name="p394">Perry, p. 394.</ref> The next day, Miller beat May four times and then had Watson caught in the gully in his third over. He then removed Bailey and Trueman. Miller's 5/72 was largely responsible for England falling for 171.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p394"/> Australia was in difficulty at 3/69 when Miller came to bat, hitting a counterattacking 30. Australia set England 371 to win. Miller removed Graveney at the start of the run chase.<ref>Perry, pp. 395–396.</ref> Resuming the next morning, he bowled Watson, and had May and Evans both caught behind. He bowled [[Johnny Wardle]] and took his only ten-wicket match haul in Tests. Australia won by 185 runs and Miller had bowled 70.1 overs for the match.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p397">Perry, p. 397.</ref> His knee had taken a heavy toll and Miller was given an extended break had to play purely as a batsman in the Third Test at Headingley.<ref name=w286>Whitington, p. 286.</ref> Australia were caught on a wet wicket in response to England's 325,<ref name="p401">Perry, p. 401.</ref> and Miller top-scored with 41 and Australia were forced to follow on.<ref name="p402">Perry, p. 402.</ref> He had attempted to keep Laker and Lock at bay with his pads.<ref name=w288>Whitington, p. 288.</ref> In the second innings, Miller fell for 26 to Laker. Australia lost by an innings,<ref name="p403">Perry, p. 403.</ref> for the first time in a Test in 18 years.<ref name="auslist">{{cite web|url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/guru?sdb=team;team=AUS;class=testteam;filter=basic;opposition=0;notopposition=0;decade=0;homeaway=0;continent=0;country=0;notcountry=0;groundid=0;season=0;startdefault=1877-03-15;start=1877-03-15;enddefault=2007-11-20;end=2007-11-20;tourneyid=0;finals=0;daynight=0;toss=0;scheduledovers=0;scheduleddays=0;innings=0;followon=0;result=0;seriesresult=0;captainid=0;recent=;viewtype=resultlist;runslow=;runshigh=;wicketslow=;wicketshigh=;ballslow=;ballshigh=;overslow=;overshigh=;bpo=0;batevent=;conclow=;conchigh=;takenlow=;takenhigh=;ballsbowledlow=;ballsbowledhigh=;oversbowledlow=;oversbowledhigh=;bpobowled=0;bowlevent=;submit=1;.cgifields=viewtype|title=Statsguru – Australia – Tests – Results list|publisher=ESPNcricinfo|accessdate=21 December 2007}}</ref>
The Australian press attacked the team, and called for changes,<ref name="p404"/> including the omission of the captain, Johnson.<ref name="p404"/><ref name="Barnes">Smith (1999), p. 187.</ref><ref name="Robinson">Robinson, p. 245.</ref> Johnson, Miller and [[Gil Langley]] were the tour selectors. Langley and Miller were willing to omit Johnson only if the captain volunteered to stand aside. Johnson did not volunteer, so the others did not discuss the topic.<ref name="p404">Perry, p. 404.</ref><ref name="Miller">Miller (1956), p. 138.</ref><ref>Whitington, pp. 289–290.</ref> Miller and Johnson had both been appointed as [[Order of the British Empire|Members of the Order of the British Empire]] (MBE) in the 1956 [[New Year Honours]],<ref>{{LondonGazette|issue=40670|supp=yes|startpage=41|date=30 December 1955|accessdate=2 July 2008}}</ref> and between the Tests they attended their formal investiture.<ref name="p404"/>
The curator at Old Trafford had been ordered to prepare a dusty, spinning pitch for the Fourth Test.<ref>Whitington, pp. 290–292.</ref> A win for England would see them retain the Ashes.<ref name="p406">Perry, p. 406.</ref> Miller bowled 21 wicketless overs as England amassed 459. Miller was out for six and a duck and fell twice to Laker, who took a world record 19 wickets as Australia lost by an innings.<ref name="p408">Perry, p. 408.</ref> ''Wisden'' reported that the Australians were said "to be extremely bitter over the condition of the pitch".<ref name="EvA4thT56Wisden">{{cite web|year = 1957|url = http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152629.html|title = Fourth Test Match: England v Australia 1956|work = Wisden Cricketers' Almanack – online archive|publisher = John Wisden & Co|accessdate =7 June 2008}}</ref>
Miller then took 5/84 against Surrey, before leading the team against Warwickshire. He had received death threats in the lead-up to the game, ordering him to lose. He scored 46 not out and took 2/13 as Australia won by an innings.<ref name="p409"/> He then took 5/29 in the second innings against Lancashire and made 50 and took match figures of 5/78 against Essex.<ref name="p409">Perry, p. 409.</ref>
On the eve of the Fifth Test at The Oval, Miller announced that the tour would be his last, so that he would retire from cricket after the tour of the [[Indian subcontinent]] on the return voyage. In his final Test on English soil, he took 4/91 in the first innings. Miller came in to bat at 5/47 and helped Australia recover to 202, top-scoring with 61.<ref>Perry, pp. 410–411.</ref> He took another one wicket in the second innings and was unbeaten on seven when stumps were drawn in the second innings. The series ended 1–2.<ref name="p411">Perry, p. 411.</ref> He ended the series with 199 runs at 28.43 and topped the bowling with 21 wickets at 22.23.<ref name="testlist"/><ref name="p413">Perry, p. 413.</ref> He topped the first-class bowling for the Australians with 50 wickets at 19.60.<ref name="p414">Perry, p. 414.</ref>
Australia played [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] at [[Karachi]] in the first Test between the two countries on a [[cricket pitch|matting pitch]], rather than the more familiar grass pitch.<ref name="PvA1956wisden">{{cite web|year = 1957|url = http://content-aus.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152645.html|title = Test Match: The unplayable Mahmood|work = Wisden Cricketers' Almanack – online archive|publisher = John Wisden & Co|accessdate =9 June 2008}}</ref> Miller top-scored in the first innings with 21, as Australia fell for 80.<ref name="p414" /> He took 2/40 and then scored 11 in the second innings as Australia fell to defeat.<ref name="p415"/> It was the last Test of his career, as his knee injury deteriorated to the point that he could not play in the three Tests against India, and retired upon his return to Australia.<ref name="p415">Perry, p. 415.</ref>
==Style and personality== [[File:Miller cut.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Miller playing a cut shot]] Miller combined classy strokeplay with big hitting, his front foot play especially devastating. He had a rifle like straight drive, played pull and sweep shots with a minimum of effort and was able to cut elegantly. He combined this elegance with unorthodoxy, hitting two [[Boundary (cricket)|sixes]] over square leg with a backhand tennis shot and once beginning the day's play in a Test match with a six.<ref name="Pollard"/> One straight [[six (cricket)|six]] that he hit at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] was still rising when it hit the first deck of the M.A. Noble Stand.<ref name="a115"/> Len Hutton said he was "the most unpredictable cricketer I have played against".<ref name="SMH"/>
As a bowler, Miller had a classically high arm action, moving the ball sharply either way and able to make the ball rise from a good length. His action caused opposition batsmen to perceive that his deliveries were gaining pace after pitching.<ref name="a115"/> He was often able to generate more pace than his new ball partner, Lindwall.<ref name="Pollard"/> He was always willing to try something new if the batsman were set, varying his approach from fifteen paces to five and vice versa. A round arm delivery often managed to capture a wicket, surprising the batsman.<ref name="Pollard"/> Compton said that Miller "often had no preconceived idea what he intended to bowl even as he turned to start his run".<ref name="a115" /> Miller often mixed slow [[leg break]]s when he was bowling off a run. He once bowled English opening batsman [[David Sheppard]] with a [[googly]] during a Test.<ref name="a115"/> Hutton opined that Miller was the bowler who was least concerned with the position of his bowling mark, and said that he "never felt physically safe against him".<ref name="a115"/> His use of [[bouncer (cricket)|bouncers]] at [[Trent Bridge]] during the 1948 tour was seen as excessive by the English crowd, who booed him. Miller simply sat down until the barracking had subsided. He was often required to bowl through pain, pressing a disk into place at the base of his spine before sending down the next delivery.<ref name="Cricinfo"/>
[[File:Ray Lindwall, late 1940s.jpg|thumb|upright|Ray Lindwall, Miller's good friend and bowling partner]] Miller and Lindwall formed an opening partnership that was regarded as one of the greatest of all time.<ref name=m72>Mallett, p. 72.</ref> Hutton said that the pair was the most hostile that he faced during his career. [[Alan Davidson (cricketer, born 1929)|Alan Davidson]], a bowling all rounder who supported Lindwall and Miller for New South Wales and Australia, said that "Ray Lindwall was the best bowler I ever saw of any type; his control was just perfect. At the other end you had Miller, who was unpredictable...It really was a perfect team."<ref name="a115"/> He was an acrobatic slips fielder, who would take freakish catches with nonchalant ease, often immediately returning to his discussion with those around him as if nothing was unusual.<ref name="Pollard"/>
Miller often required a contest to retain interest in the game. He deplored Bradman's ruthless attitude towards annihilating the opposition and sometimes refused to try when Australia was in an unassailable position. At [[Southend]] in 1948, as the Australians scored a world record 721 runs in a single day against [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]], Miller, coming in to bat when the score was 2/364, allowed himself to be bowled first ball.<ref name="Cricinfo"/> Indeed, he "turned to the wicketkeeper and said: "Thank God that's over"."<ref name="SMH"/> His teammate [[Sid Barnes]] said that if Miller "had the same outlook as Bradman or Ponsford he would have made colossal scores" and become "the statisticians' greatest customer".<ref name="a117">Armstrong, p. 117.</ref>
Miller never captained Australia in a Test, as his attitude to the game tended to alarm the authorities. About Miller, [[Ashley Mallett]] wrote, "He loved tradition, but hated convention. His unstructured way of playing and living would be anathema to cricketers now... He played as he fought the war, by impulse and mood."<ref name="SMH"/> He sometimes set his field by saying to his players: "scatter".<ref name=po80/><ref name="m66" /> On another occasion, he is reported turned to his players, after being told that NSW was taking the field with one player too many, and asked for one player to volunteer to "piss off".<ref name=po80/><ref name="m66"/>
A larger than life character, Miller is the subject of many stories, often [[apocryphal]]. One story had Don Bradman answering a knock on the door late one night to see Miller dressed in a dinner suit. Miller advised Bradman that, as demanded, he was in bed at curfew and was now going out.<ref name="SMH"/> His relationship with Bradman was one riddled with friction and mutual antipathy, "... one a roundhead of massive influence, the other a cavalier and maverick".<ref name=Selvey/> As Bradman moved from batting hero and team captain to selector and administrator, his influence grew; this "... almost certainly cost Miller any chance of captaining his country".<ref name="Selvey"/>
One night, following a duel with [[Messerschmitt]]s in his [[de Havilland Mosquito|Mosquito]], he made an unauthorised detour over [[Bonn]] because it was [[Beethoven]]'s birthplace and he was a lover of the classics.<ref name="SMH"/> Despite his fame, Miller remained a humble man; when asked his favourite cricketing memory, he would recall no incident concerning himself, but "a South Australian team-mate walking onto Lord's to a thunderous ovation a few weeks after his release from a POW camp".<ref name="SMH"/> The cricket broadcaster, [[John Arlott]] said "that for all the glamour that attached to Miller, he was staunch and unaffected as a friend".<ref name="SMH"/>
When asked how he managed to take seven wickets for just 12 runs against South Australia, Miller replied:
<blockquote>There's three reasons, First, I bowled bloody well. Second, I, errr ... second ..." [pause]. "You can forget about the other two reasons."<ref name="Haigh2">{{cite news | first = Haigh | last = Gideon | authorlink = Gideon Haigh | title = No beating about the bush, Miller was Australian in excelsis | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2004/oct/12/cricket | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 12 October 2004 | accessdate =22 December 2007 }}</ref></blockquote>
==Later life== [[File:Miller family.JPG|thumb|Miller and his first wife and sons, pictured in the 1950s]] After retirement, Miller remained in the public eye, augmented by persistent "unsubstantiated rumours of an affair with [[Princess Margaret, Countess of Snowdon|Princess Margaret]]".<ref name="Cricinfo"/> He made a living as a journalist and columnist, employed by the ''[[Daily Express]]'' as a "special cricket writer" for twenty years.<ref name=Selvey/><ref>Perry, pp. 426–430.</ref> As during his career, Miller was a proponent of attacking and bright play. He praised the aggressive leadership of his protege [[Richie Benaud]] but criticised the style of play pursued by Australia under Benaud's successors [[Bob Simpson (cricketer)|Bob Simpson]] and [[Bill Lawry]].<ref>Perry, pp. 434, 439.</ref> In the mid-1980s, when Australia was struggling, Miller called for the removal of [[Allan Border]], an obdurate and defensive batsman, from the captaincy.<ref name=p461>Perry, p. 461.</ref>
He later worked for [[Football pools|Vernons Pools]], owned by the millionaire horseracing entrepreneur, [[Robert Sangster]].<ref name="Selvey">{{cite news | first = Mike | last = Selvey | authorlink = Mike Selvey | title = Obituary: Keith Miller | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2004/oct/12/guardianobituaries.cricket | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 12 October 2004 | accessdate =14 January 2008 }}</ref> However, Miller "was happiest at the cricket or at the races".<ref name="Cricinfo"/> He also worked as the head of a lobby group in promoting [[Australian rules football]] in his adopted New South Wales in the 1980s. At the time, the VFL was the dominant league and there were no top-flight teams in his adopted state or [[Queensland]].<ref>Perry, pp. 461–462.</ref>
Miller's later life was plagued by ill health. In November 1991, he was hospitalised with a stroke, and soon after fell over and broke his hip, necessitating two further operations. He had [[skin cancer]], caused by his insistence on always displaying his mop of hair and not wearing a hat. He accepted these vicissitudes equably. "Some grieved to see him reduced, but not him; these were life's deliveries. He knew only that one would get him out eventually." He had an earlobe removed. The cancer also attacked his legs, and coupled with his hip injury, severely curtailed his mobility, forcing him to use walking frames and wheelchairs.<ref name=SMH/><ref name=p468>Perry, p. 468.</ref> Asked at 75 about death, he said: "Never think about it. No regrets. I've had a hell of a good life. Been damned lucky."<ref name="SMH"/>
Despite his illnesses, he continued to travel to England in the 1990s to watch cricket and meet up with Compton, Edrich and other war and cricket colleagues on an annual basis, although he became increasingly isolated as he outlasted his friends, both English and Australian.<ref>Perry, pp. 464–480.</ref>
In late 2002, Miller divorced his wife Peg,<ref>Perry, p. 481.</ref> with whom he had four sons. He did so to marry his long-term mistress Marie Challman, with whom he had been living since 1999. Challman was a hospital receptionist and Miller reasoned that he would receive more effective medical treatment by moving to Melbourne to live with her, as his specialist doctors also lived there.<ref>Perry, pp. 477–480.</ref> He had other long-term mistresses, including an Australian beauty queen with whom he was photographed in public.<ref>Perry, pp. 391–398.</ref> During his later years, his illness contributed to what his family felt was a deteriorating attitude and he fell out with his sons, but they were reconciled shortly before his death.<ref>Perry, pp. 476–482.</ref>
Miller died in October 2004 after being in persistent poor health.<ref name="Cricinfo"/> He was given a state funeral by the [[Government of Victoria]], which saw hundreds of mourners stand outside the packed cathedral, and was broadcast across the nation on [[ABC Radio National|ABC Radio]].<ref>Perry, pp. 484–486.</ref>
==Legacy and statistical analysis== <!-- this should not be listy --> [[File:Klarfeld Australian Cricketer Keith Miller.jpg|thumb|upright|Life-size bronze statue of Miller outside Melbourne High School, sculpted by [[Linda Klarfeld]]]] Miller's achievements were recognised by a host of awards during his lifetime and posthumously. Miller was one of the ten inaugural inductees into the [[Australian Cricket Hall of Fame]] in 1996.<ref>Perry, p. 475.</ref> In 2000, he was named in the [[Australian Cricket Board Team of the Century]] as its vice-captain.<ref name=p478>Perry, p. 478.</ref> In January 2010, Miller was inducted into the [[ICC Cricket Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thesportscampus.com/201001043276/news-bytes/icc-hall-of-fame-inductees-jan2010 |title=Lindwall, Miller, O'Reilly, Trumper and Waugh – Australian legends inducted into ICC Cricket Hall of Fame}}</ref>
He is also one of only four Australian cricketers, (the others being Bradman, [[Victor Trumper]] and [[Shane Warne]]) to be honoured with a portrait in the Long Room at [[Lord's]] in London.<ref name="Selvey"/><ref>The following sources are, respectively, a Miller obituary from 2004, which lists Trumper and Bradman and a further piece from 2005, when Warne's portrait was added. [[Mike Atherton]], the author of the second piece, curiously overlooks Trumper's portrait; other articles of the same period do similarly.</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/cricket/2360948/Warne-still-the-incomparable-master-of-spin-bowler%27s-craft.html |title=Warne: still the incomparable master of spin bowler's craft |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |first=Michael |last=Atherton |authorlink=Michael Atherton |date=11 June 2005 |accessdate=5 February 2009}}</ref> Miller is one of only three men (the others being [[Vinoo Mankad|M.H. "Vinoo" Mankad]] and [[Garfield Sobers|G.StA. "Garry" Sobers]]) to have his name on both the batting and bowling honours boards in the visitors' dressing-room there, for scoring both a century and for taking five wickets in a test at the ground.<ref name="Cricinfo"/>
Miller's abilities as an all-rounder led to enormous success as both batsman and bowler. The [[ICC player rankings]] have been applied retrospectively to cricket history and Miller achieved top ten rankings with both bat and ball. As a batsman, he peaked at ninth in the world in 1952, and was a top-20 player from shortly after his début and for the rest of the duration of his career.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.lgiccrankings.com/test/batting/player-display.php?id=725&graph=ranking |title = Keith Miller Batting Test Ranking Statistics |publisher = LG ICC Rankings |accessdate =2 January 2008}}</ref> Miller's bowling abilities led to even greater success. By the end of 1946, he was already ranked sixth in the world and thereafter never slipped lower than ninth; for much of his career, he was the second-best bowler in the world according to the ratings, remarkably, for a 36-year-old, peaking at the number 1 slot for a few months in 1956.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.lgiccrankings.com/test/bowling/player-display.php?graph=ranking&id=725 |title = Keith Miller Bowling Test Ranking Statistics |publisher = LG ICC Rankings |accessdate =2 January 2008}}</ref> As an all-rounder, therefore, it is unsurprising to find that he was peerless for most of his career, ranked as number one in the world for most of his career, including an unbroken eight-year run from June 1948 until his retirement.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.lgiccrankings.com/test/all-rounder/player-display.php?id=725&graph=ranking |title =Keith Miller All-Rounder Test Ranking Statistics |publisher = LG ICC Rankings |accessdate =2 January 2008}}</ref>
Miller's statistics are an inexact measure of his worth to the side. Many of the Australia teams he played in featured very strong batting line-ups, restricting his opportunities as a middle-order player.<ref>Perry, pp. 183–186, 223.</ref> His verve and enthusiasm were also important contributors to Australian success, as was his ability to produce the unexpected (particularly with the ball) and help break partnerships.<ref name="m65" /> It is for this reason that he is remembered for his personality and his one-off feats, more than statistical accomplishment; in [[Ian Chappell]]'s words "People who saw it still talk of Keith Miller's [[Six (cricket)|monster shot]] that hit the Members Stand clock at the SCG in the 1950s".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chappell|first1=Ian|title=The sixes don't add up|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/399274.html|website=ESPN Cricinfo}}</ref>
